L. Health And Sanitation Inspections: Professions, occupations, businesses and/or commercial establishments operated within the corporate limits of the
city and subject to health and sanitation regulations of the city are assessed a fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) (included in the license fee) to cover the
cost of four (4) inspections and one return visit for violation. A fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) will be assessed for each additional inspection required.
(Ord. 0-98-49, 11-16-1998, eff. 11-26-1998)
3-1A-4: SUSPENSION OF LICENSES:
A. Any license issued under this article may be suspended temporarily by the health inspector for failure of the licensee to comply with the requirements of
this chapter or for violation of any other provision of any city ordinance relating to the conduct of the business, the condition of the premises or vehicle,
the article of food dealt in, or the license required; provided, however, that no license shall be suspended hereunder until notice has been given to the
licensee as provided in section 3-1-11 of this chapter and until a reasonable time has elapsed to enable the licensee to comply with the provisions of
this chapter or other ordinances of the city. Such notice shall state that the licensee is entitled to a hearing before the public safety committee if a
written request for such a hearing is filed by the licensee with the public safety committee.
B. Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter to the contrary, whenever the health inspector finds unsanitary or other conditions in the operation of
a food establishment or food vehicle which, in his judgment, constitutes a substantial hazard to the public health, he may without warning, notice or
hearing issue a written notice to the license holder or operator citing such condition, specifying the corrective action to be taken, and specifying the time
period within which such action shall be taken; and if deemed necessary, such order shall state that the license is immediately suspended, and all food
operations are to be immediately, discontinued. Any person to whom such an order is issued shall comply immediately therewith, but upon written
petition to the public safety committee, shall be afforded a hearing no later than seventy two (72) hours after receipt of the petition by the committee.
(Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1A-5: REINSTATEMENT OF SUSPENDED LICENSES:
Any person whose license under this chapter has been suspended may, at any time, make application for reinspection for the purpose of reinstatement of
the license. Within ten (10) days following receipt of a written request, including a statement signed by the applicant that in his opinion the conditions
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 100/470
causing suspension of the license have been corrected, the health inspector shall make a reinspection. If the applicant is complying with all applicable
ordinances, the license shall be reinstated. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1A-6: HEARINGS:
The hearings provided for hereunder shall be conducted by the public safety committee at a time and place designated by them. Based upon the record of
such hearing, the public safety committee shall make a finding and shall sustain, modify or rescind any official notice or order considered in the hearing. A
written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the licensee by the public safety committee. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1A-7: CONDITIONAL LICENSE:
Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter to the contrary, when structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation, or similar such defects exist in an
established food facility that may require significant expenditures to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards, a conditional license
may be granted at the discretion of the health inspector. Under no circumstances will a conditional license be issued for more than two (2) consecutive
twelve (12) month periods. The purpose of the conditional license or permit is to allow a reasonable period of time for correction of existing defects. (Ord.
0-88-13, 4-18-1988; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
ARTICLE B. FOOD DEALERS
3-1B-1: REGULATIONS:
Every licensed food dealer shall comply strictly with all the provisions of the ordinances of the city relating to health, sanitation and food establishments
and all other applicable ordinances of the city. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1B-2: INSPECTIONS:
The health inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as he deems necessary the premises and operations of every food dealer in the city to
determine whether all applicable provisions of the ordinances of the city are being complied with. Such inspections shall be conducted in accordance with
the provisions of section 3-1-11 of this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
ARTICLE C. FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
3-1C-1: MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS:
A. All milk and milk products, including fluid milk, other fluid dairy products and manufactured milk products, which are used or served in food service
establishments, shall meet the standards of quality established for such products by applicable state and local laws and regulations.
B. Only pasteurized fluid milk and fluid milk products shall be used or served. Dry milk and milk products may be reconstituted in the food service
establishment if used for cooking purposes only. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
C. All milk and fluid milk products for drinking purposes shall be purchased and served in the original individual container in which they were packaged at
the milk plant, or shall be served from an approved bulk milk dispenser; provided, that cream, whipped cream or half and half, which is to be consumed
on the premises, may be served from the original container of not more than one-half (1/2) gallon capacity or from a dispenser approved by the health
inspector for such service, and for mixed drinks requiring less than one-half (1/2) pint of milk, milk may be poured from one quart or one-half (1/2) gallon
containers packaged at a milk plant. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1C-2: BAKERY PRODUCTS:
All bakery products used shall have been prepared in the food service establishment or in a food processing establishment; provided, that the health
inspector may accept other sources which are in his judgment satisfactory and which are in compliance with the applicable state and local laws and
regulations. Custards, cream fillings or similar products, which are used as puddings or pastry fillings, shall be kept at safe temperatures, except during
necessary periods of preparation and service. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1C-3: FOOD PROTECTION:
A. Raw fruits and vegetables used shall be washed before use. Stuffings, poultry, stuffed meats and poultry and pork and pork products shall be
thoroughly cooked before being served. Individual portions of food once served to the customer shall not be served again; provided, that wrapped food
which has not been unwrapped and which is wholesome may be reserved.
B. Only such poisonous and toxic materials as are required to maintain sanitary conditions and for sanitation purposes may be used or stored in food
service establishments. Poisonous and toxic materials shall be identified, and shall be used only in such manner under such conditions as will not
contaminate food or constitute a hazard to employees or customers. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 101/470
3-1C-4: MANUAL CONTACT WITH FOOD:
A. Convenient and suitable utensils shall be provided and shall be used by employees to reduce manual contact with food to a minimum during
preparation, display and service. For self-service by customers, similar instruments shall be provided.
B. Self-service openings in counter guards shall be so designed and arranged as to protect food from manual contact by customers. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-
1977)
C. Dispensing scoops, spoons and dippers used in serving frozen desserts shall be stored, between uses, either in an approved running water dipperwell,
or in a manner approved by the health inspector. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
D. Sugar shall be provided only in closed dispensers or in individual packages. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1C-5: EQUIPMENT AND UTENSILS1:
A. All eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized after each usage as hereinafter provided.
B. Single service articles shall be made from nontoxic materials. All single service articles shall be stored, handled and dispensed in a sanitary manner,
and shall be used only once.
C. Food service establishments which do not have adequate and effective facilities for cleaning and sanitizing utensils shall use single service articles only.
D. Cloths used by waiters, chefs and other personnel shall be cleaned, and any such cloths used wiping food contact surfaces shall be used for no other
purposes. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1C-6: WASHING AND SANITIZING METHODS, FACILITIES:
A. Prior to washing, all equipment and utensils shall be preflushed or prescraped and, when necessary, presoaked to remove gross food particles and soil.
B. Effective concentrations of a suitable detergent shall be used in both manual and mechanical dishwashing.
C. When manual dishwashing is employed, equipment and utensils shall be thoroughly washed in a detergent solution which is kept reasonably clean, and
then shall be rinsed free of such solution. All eating and drinking utensils and, where required, the food contact surfaces of all other equipment and
utensils shall be sanitized by one of the following methods:
1. Immersion for at least one-half (1/2) minute in clean hot water at a temperature of at least one hundred seventy degrees Fahrenheit (170F).
2. Immersion for a period of at least one minute in a sanitizing solution containing:
a. At least fifty (50) ppm of available chlorine at a temperature not less than seventy five degrees Fahrenheit (75F); or
b. At least twelve and five-tenths (12.5) ppm of available iodine in a solution having a pH not higher than 5.0 and a temperature of not less than
seventy five degrees Fahrenheit (75F); or (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
c. Any other chemical sanitizing agent which has been demonstrated to the satisfaction of the health inspector to be effective and nontoxic under use
conditions, and for which a suitable field test is available. Such sanitizing agents, in use solutions, shall provide the equivalent bactericidal effect of
a solution containing at least fifty (50) ppm of available chlorine at a temperature not less than seventy five degrees Fahrenheit (75F).
Bactericides which, in recommended concentration, produce a 99.999 percent kill of 75-125 million M. pyogenes var. aureus FDA 209 per ml.,
within thirty (30) seconds, at seventy degrees (70) to seventy five degrees Fahrenheit (75F), shall be considered satisfactory. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-
1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
The strength of sanitizing solutions shall be at least twice the minimum strength required for the particular sanitizing solution used.
3. Equipment too large to treat by methods in subsections C1 and C2 of this section may be treated:
a. With live steam from a hose, in the case of equipment in which steam can be confined; or
b. By rinsing with boiling water; or
c. By spraying or swabbing with a chemical sanitizing solution of at least twice the minimum strength required for the particular sanitizing solution
when used for immersion sanitization. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
D. A three (3) compartment sink shall be provided and used wherever washing and sanitization of equipment or utensils are conducted manually;
provided, that establishments where the only utensils to be washed are limited to spatulas, tongs and similar devices, and when the only equipment to
be cleaned is stationary and does not require disassembly for proper cleaning, a one compartment sink may be approved by the health inspector for
this purpose. At least a two (2) compartment sink shall be provided and used for washing kitchenware and equipment which does not require
sanitization. Single compartment utility sinks such as cooks' and bakers' sinks may be used for the rinsing of utensils. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd.
Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 102/470
E. Sinks used for manual washing and sanitizing operations shall be of adequate length, width and depth to permit the complete immersion of the
equipment and utensils, and each compartment of such sinks shall be supplied with hot and cold running water. Dish baskets shall be of such design
as to permit complete immersion of the utensils and equipment components being sanitized therein.
F. When hot water is used as the sanitizing agent in manual operations, thermometers, accurate to three degrees Fahrenheit (3F), shall be provided
convenient to the sink to permit frequent checks of the water temperature.
G. Dish tables and drainboards of adequate size for proper handling of soiled utensils prior to washing and for cleaned utensils following rinsing or
sanitization, shall be provided, and shall be so located or constructed as not to interfere with the proper use of the dishwashing facilities; provided, that
drainboards shall not be required for cooks' and bakers' rinse sinks.
H. Sinks, dish tables and drainboards shall be constructed of galvanized metal or better, suitably reinforced, of such thickness and design as to resist
denting and buckling, and sloped so as to be self-draining.
I. Dishwashing machines shall be of such materials and so designed and constructed as to be easily cleanable, and shall be capable, when operated
properly, of rendering all surfaces of equipment and utensils clean to sight and touch and sanitized.
J. When spray type dishwashing machines are used, the following additional requirements shall be met:
1. Wash water shall be kept reasonably clean, and rinse water tanks shall be so protected by distance, baffles, or other effective means as to minimize
the entry of wash water into the rinse water.
2. The flow pressure shall be not less than fifteen (15) nor more than twenty five (25) pounds per square inch on the water line at the machine, and not
less than ten (10) pounds per square inch at the rinse nozzles. A suitable gauge cock shall be provided immediately upstream from the final rinse
sprays to permit checking the flow pressure of the final rinse water. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3. The wash water temperature shall be at least one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150F) and in single tank conveyor machines shall be at least
one hundred sixty degrees Fahrenheit (160F). When hot water is relied upon for sanitization, the final or fresh rinse water shall be at a temperature
of at least one hundred eighty degrees Fahrenheit (180F) at the entrance of the manifold. When a pumped rinse is provided, the water shall be at a
temperature of at least one hundred seventy degrees Fahrenheit (170F). When chemicals are relied upon for sanitization, they shall be of a class or
type approved by the health inspector, and shall be applied in such concentration and for such a period of time as to provide effective bactericidal
treatment of the equipment and utensils. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
4. Conveyors in dishwashing machines shall be accurately timed to assure proper exposure times in wash and rinse cycles.
5. An easily readable thermometer shall be provided in each tank of the dishwashing machine which will indicate to within an accuracy of three degrees
Fahrenheit (3F) the temperature of the water or solution therein. In addition, a thermometer of equal accuracy shall be provided which will indicate
the temperature of the final rinse water as it enters the manifold.
6. Jets, nozzles and all other parts of each machine shall be maintained free of chemical deposits, debris and other soil. Automatic detergent
dispensers, if used, shall be kept in proper operating condition.
K. When an immersion type dishwashing machine is employed for equipment and utensil washing and sanitizing, the applicable requirements pertaining to
manual dishwashing shall be met; provided, that a two (2) compartment system shall be deemed adequate when the temperature of the wash water is
maintained at or above one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit (140F) and hot water at a temperature of at least one hundred eighty degrees
Fahrenheit (180F) is used as the sanitizing agent. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
L. Any other type of machine, device or facilities and procedures may be approved by the health inspector for cleaning or sanitizing equipment and
utensils, if it can be readily established that such machine, device or facilities and procedures will routinely render equipment and utensils clean to sight
and touch, and provide effective bactericidal treatment as demonstrated by an average plate count per utensil surface examined, of not more than ten
(10) colonies. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1C-7: WATER SUPPLY:
A. The water supply in a food service establishment shall be adequate, of a safe, sanitary quality, and from an approved source. Hot and cold running
water, under pressure, shall be provided in all areas where food is prepared, or equipment, utensils or containers are washed.
B. Water, if not piped into the establishment, shall be transported and stored in approved containers, and shall be handled and dispensed in a sanitary
manner.
C. Ice used for any purpose shall be made from water from an approved source, and shall be used only after it has been manufactured, stored,
transported and handled in a sanitary manner. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1C-8: SANITARY REQUIREMENTS2:
A. Toilet Facilities: Toilet facilities shall comply strictly with subsection 3-1-8D of this chapter and all other applicable ordinances of the city.
B. Hand Washing Facilities:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 103/470
1. Lavatories shall be located within or immediately adjacent to all toilet rooms or vestibules. In all new establishments, and establishments which are
extensively altered, lavatories shall also be located within the area where the food is prepared.
2. Lavatories shall be adequate in size and number and shall be so located as to permit convenient and expeditious use by all employees. (Ord. 0-77-
13, 5-2-1977)
3. Lavatories shall be installed in accordance with applicable state and local laws, ordinances and regulations, or in the absence thereof, as approved
by the health inspector. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
4. Each lavatory shall be provided with hot and cold or tempered running water. Where hot and cold running water is provided, a mixing valve or
combination faucet is recommended and shall be required in new installations. Steam mixing valves are prohibited.
5. An adequate supply of hand cleansing soap or detergent shall be available at each lavatory. An adequate supply of sanitary towels, or an approved
hand drying device, shall be available and conveniently located near the lavatory. Common towels are prohibited. Where disposable towels are used,
waste receptacles shall be located conveniently near the hand washing facilities.
6. Lavatories, soap dispensers, hand drying devices, and all other components of the hand washing facilities shall be kept clean and in good repair.
C. Restrictions: Food vehicles are permitted to operate only on streets one block removed from public or parochial school grounds or municipal
playgrounds. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1C-9: TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS:
A temporary food service establishment shall comply with all provisions of this chapter which are applicable to its operation; provided, that the health
inspector may augment such requirements when needed to assure the service of safe food and may prohibit the sale of potentially hazardous food. (Ord.
0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1C-10: FOOD SERVICE VEHICLES:
A. General:
1. The term "food service vehicle" when used in this section shall mean a food service establishment operated in a vehicle.
2. Food service vehicles shall be subject to the regulations in this section as well as to all other regulations governing food vehicles and food service
establishments.
3. Only single service food utensils shall be used for food service vehicles.
4. No food service vehicle shall stop in any location that is not reasonably clean and sanitary. The operator of such vehicle shall be responsible for
sanitation of the environs of the place of operation. Every food service vehicle shall maintain suitable, tight, nonabsorbent, washable receptacles for
refuse, which shall be attached to but not an integral part of the vehicle.
B. Service Of Food From Vehicles:
1. It shall be unlawful to serve food from a vehicle or for food to be served by a food service vehicle except as provided in subsections B2 through B7 of
this section.
2. Coffee, sugar and cream shall be served only in approved containers. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3. Coffee is to be prepared in a commercial food processing establishment. Cream is to be refrigerated and kept in a covered single service container,
or in an approved cream dispenser. Nondairy creamers are exempt from this requirement. Sugar shall be served only in wrapped individual
packages or in a covered closed pouring spout type container, or in any other manner approved by the health inspector which is effective in
preventing contamination by the customer. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
4. Other bulk soft drinks or beverages shall be dispensed from an approved dispenser and shall be protected from flies, dust and contamination by
customers.
5. All food products shall be completely enclosed, covered and protected while being conveyed, transported or dispensed.
6. Ice cream, ice milk, frozen dessert mix, sodas, sundaes manufactured or processed on or served from the mobile vehicle shall be prepared from
ingredients dispensed from an approved dispenser only. Customers shall be served in single service containers.
7. Except as provided in subsections B2 through B6 of this section, no food other than individual portions that are totally enclosed in a wrapper and that
have been prepared in a commercial food processing establishment shall be served from a vehicle or by a food service vehicle. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-
1977)
3-1C-11: INSPECTIONS:
The health inspector shall inspect the premises of every food service establishment located in the city at least once every six (6) months. More frequent
inspections may be made if the health inspector deems it necessary. Such inspections shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of section 3-1-
11 of this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1C-12: STATE LAWS APPLICABLE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 104/470
Whenever the provisions contained in this chapter are less restrictive than the food service sanitation code, 1998 edition, printed by the state of Illinois,
department of public health, such food service sanitation code, as the case may be, shall be applicable to food establishments and food dealers in the city,
and for such purposes said food service sanitation code is hereby adopted by reference of the aforementioned rules and regulations. A minimum of three
(3) copies of such code shall be kept on file by the city clerk. (Ord. 0-00-24, 9-18-2000)
ARTICLE D. RESTAURANTS; ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS
3-1D-1: DEFINITION:
A "restaurant", within the meaning of this Chapter, shall be deemed to be any land, building or part thereof, other than a boarding house, where food is
provided for compensation for three (3) or more persons, including a cafe, cafeteria, coffee shop, lunchroom, tearoom and dining room, including drive-in
facilities or other establishments wherein prepared and cooked food is dispensed for consumption on or off the premises. For the purpose of preserving
the public peace, health and safety, the entire premises occupied by a restaurant, together with means of ingress and egress, are subject to regulation
under the provisions of this Article. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1D-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
The following acts or conduct of any person entering any restaurant or premises are hereby declared to be unlawful and any person found guilty of any
such act shall be fined as provided by Section 3-1-16 of this Chapter:
A. No person on the premises of a restaurant shall race the motor of any vehicle, needlessly bring to a sudden start or stop any motor vehicle, blow any
horn of any motor vehicle or cause to be made any loud or unseemly noise, nuisance, or disturbance whereby the quiet and good order of the premises
of the neighborhood are disturbed.
B. No person shall enter the premises of any restaurant with any motor vehicle of any description, and park such vehicle and leave the premises (thereby
leaving such vehicle parked and unoccupied) without the express consent of the owner or operator of such restaurant; in which event, said motor
vehicle may be subject to a parking citation or may be impounded subject to the usual impounding charges.
C. No person shall enter the premises in or upon a motor vehicle and use said premises for cruising, racing, as a shortcut to another street, or to annoy or
endanger any person or other vehicle lawfully on said premises.
D. No persons shall congregate on the premises and linger or loiter at any location on the premises of any restaurant other than in the restaurant building
or in a legally parked motor vehicle for any purpose other than the prompt consumption of foodstuffs purchased therein, upon the conclusion of which,
such persons shall promptly vacate the premises.
E. No person, while on the premises of any restaurant, shall wilfully discard any trash, litter, paper napkins, cups or remnants of food at any place except in
the trash receptacles as hereinafter provided for. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1D-3: DRIVE-IN ESTABLISHMENTS:
A. It is hereby declared to be a duty of the owner or operator of a drive-in restaurant to provide not less than two (2) receptacles for the receipt of trash,
litter, paper, napkins, cups and remnants of food at each exit, available to the patrons as they leave the premises, unless the owner shall provide trash
receptacles inside the lot not more than fifteen feet (15') from any parking space.
B. It shall be the duty of the restaurant operator to exercise due care to keep the premises whereon a restaurant is located, together with the parking area
and that portion of any alley adjoining said restaurant, free from rubbish, waste products and debris, including napkins, straws, paper cups and plates,
and other waste material.
C. Each drive-in restaurant operator shall, at least once in twenty four (24) hours, empty all waste receptacles, and in any event shall empty each waste
receptacle when full. At least once in each twenty four (24) hours, each drive-in restaurant operator shall pick up and remove all waste material from
the ground on the premises of the restaurant. It shall be the duty of the restaurant operator to post on the premises in a conspicuous location one or
more signs bearing the following legend in letters at least two inches (2") or more high and readable:
Cruising in or congregating and loitering on these premises is unlawful. No unoccupied vehicles may be left on the restaurant premises without the
consent of the restaurant operator.
(Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
ARTICLE E. FROZEN DESSERT ESTABLISHMENTS
3-1E-1: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
All persons conducting or operating frozen dessert establishments, whether licensed under the provisions of this chapter or under any other chapters of
this code, shall comply strictly with all the regulations of this article and with all the applicable regulations of this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 105/470
3-1E-2: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
All frozen desserts made or sold in the city shall be produced under conditions such that the frozen dessert in the process of production, preparation,
manufacture, packing, storing, sale, distribution or transportation is securely protected from flies, vermin, dogs, cats, dust, dirt and other foreign or injurious
contamination. All refuse, dirt or waste products subject to decomposition and fermentation shall be removed daily from the premises of all frozen dessert
establishments. All trucks, trays, boxes, buckets or other receptacles, and the chutes, platforms, racks, tables, shelves and knives, saws, cleavers or other
utensils or the machinery used in handling, cutting, chipping, mixing, canning or other processes shall be clean at all times. The clothing of operators or
other persons employed in frozen dessert establishments shall be clean; and adequate toilet facilities and soap and clean towels shall be provided for
employees handling frozen desserts and products entering the manufacture of the same. It shall be a violation of this chapter either to make frozen
desserts in conditions not in accordance with these requirements, or to sell frozen desserts not so made. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1E-3: CONTAGIOUS CONDITIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale in the city any frozen dessert which has been produced, prepared or handled by any person infected or
suspected of being infected with any contagious disease. When there is any such condition of contagion or suspected contagion about any place, the fact
shall be reported by the person producing frozen dessert therein and the sale and delivery of frozen dessert manufactured therein in the city shall be
stopped immediately by the health inspector. When the health inspector is satisfied that there is no longer any danger of contagion from the sale of frozen
desserts produced therein, he shall then permit such sale, but not before. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1E-4: CONDITIONS OF PRODUCT:
A. Ingredients: It shall be unlawful to make frozen desserts, or to deliver in the city frozen desserts, made from substances other than eggs, milk, cream,
condensed milk, fruits, gelatin, nuts, and harmless flavoring and coloring matters. Only such fruits and nuts may be used in the manufacture of frozen
desserts as are sound, clean, mature and nonrancid. All milk and cream used for the manufacture of frozen desserts sold or offered for sale in the city
shall be pasteurized and shall comply in other respects with the standards for milk and cream as defined by the provisions of section 3-1-1 of this
chapter.
B. Milk Fat And Bacteria Content: It shall be unlawful to make, sell or offer for sale in the city any ice cream which contains less than four percent (4%) of
milk fat. Such ice cream shall have a plate count that does not exceed thirty thousand (30,000) colonies per million, provided that bacteria are
nonpathogenic in water.
C. Refreezing Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to refreeze any frozen desserts which have melted and to sell or offer for sale any such frozen desserts which
have been refrozen.
D. Wholesomeness Of Cones: No person shall make, give, deliver, sell or offer for sale in the city any frozen dessert cones which are made under
unsanitary conditions or in any unclean manner or which contain any ingredients which are unwholesome or deleterious to health. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-
1977)
3-1E-5: STORAGE OF CONES AND PAILS:
All frozen dessert cones, fibre pails and other containers used in the sale or delivery of frozen desserts must be kept or stored in such place and manner
as to fully protect them from flies and other sources of contamination. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1E-6: UTENSILS USED IN MANUFACTURE:
All utensils and equipment used in the manufacture, handling or sale of frozen desserts shall be of nonabsorbent material, free from rust or corrosion,
constructed in such a manner that they may be easily cleaned and sterilized and shall be kept clean and sterilized at all times. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1E-7: RECEPTACLES FOR STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION:
No person shall keep or store frozen desserts for sale or disposal, or transport the same over any street, alley or way in the city, except in a receptacle
which is clean, dustproof and flyproof. Such storage receptacles shall be kept in a location and in a manner which is satisfactory to the health inspector.
(Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1E-8: INSPECTIONS:
The health inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as he deems necessary every frozen dessert establishment in the city to determine
whether all applicable provisions of the ordinances of the city are being complied with. Such inspection shall be conducted in accordance with section 3-1-
11 of this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
ARTICLE F. MILK DEALERS
3-1F-1: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 106/470
All milk dealers, whether licensed under the provisions of this chapter or under any other chapter of this code, shall comply strictly with all the regulations
of this article and with all applicable regulations of this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1F-2: STANDARDS:
A. General: All milk sold or offered for sale in the city shall meet with applicable state and federal standards. All milk, skim milk, buttermilk and cream sold
or offered for sale in the city shall conform to the standards for these products fixed by state and federal law. The sale or offering for sale of any milk or
milk products in any way not in conformity with state and federal law is prohibited.
No milk or cream shall be sold that contains any artificial preservative, or that comes from cows fed on refuse or slop, mush or food which has been
subject to fermentation, or any food other than good wholesome food.
B. Cream: No cream shall be sold, offered for sale, exchanged, delivered or kept for the purpose of sale in the city that contains less than eighteen percent
(18%) of milk fat, or that is obtained from any impure, diseased or unwholesome milk, or from milk to which any foreign substance has been added, or
from milk containing less than three percent (3%) of butterfat. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1F-3: CONTAINER SPECIFICATIONS:
No milk, except skimmed milk, buttermilk or sour milk shall be peddled or sold at retail in quantities of less than one gallon except in containers bearing the
true name of the product, the name and address of the producer, dealer or distributor, and the net volume of the contents in accordance with the Illinois
dairy statute1. No person shall sell milk or cream in any bottle or container which does not bear the seller's name or to which the seller has not acquired
title as required by law. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1F-4: PREVENTION OF INFECTION:
All milk offered for sale or sold in the city must come from animals under state and federal supervision and proven free from all contagious and infectious
diseases, and shall not contain more than twenty thousand (20,000) bacteria, most probable number per cubic centimeter, with the tolerance level of E.
coli-aerogenes group not exceeding 0-10, most probable number, and shall contain no pathogenic bacteria. It shall be produced under the following
conditions:
A. All persons coming in contact with the milk on farms, in dairies or in any other place shall be free from contagious or infectious diseases, and shall not
have been exposed to anyone having such disease within a period of one week prior to coming in contact with the milk. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
B. No person who is a paratyphoid, typhoid, diphtheria or septic sore throat carrier shall be employed in the production of handling of the milk. It shall be
the duty of every person with knowledge of the facts to notify the health inspector at once of the occurrence of any of the afflictions listed in subsection
A of this section and this subsection in any person living or employed in or about a place where milk is produced, handled or sold. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-
1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1F-5: QUARANTINED PREMISES:
A. Milk shall not be delivered to quarantined premises except in such manner that there is not contact of any kind between the inmates and contents of the
quarantined premises and the delivery agent.
B. No milk receptacles shall be taken from quarantined premises during the period of quarantine. If milk receptacles are to be taken from such premises
and reused after the quarantine has been lifted, they shall be thoroughly sealed and sterilized before being taken from the formerly quarantined
premises. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1F-6: VEHICLES:
Every vehicle used for the delivery of milk and cream to consumers shall have marked plainly on it the name of the vendor of the milk and his address.
(Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1F-7: INSPECTION:
The health inspector shall conduct periodic inspection of all milk distribution plants, dairies, vehicles and equipment used in the sale or distribution of milk
as well as of the milk itself. Such inspections shall be made every quarter and as often as the health inspector deems necessary. The inspector may, in his
discretion, accept in lieu of inspection the certificate of inspection of any other city with requirements equal to or more rigid than those of this article and
chapter 1 of this title. The licensee shall pay the cost of all bacteriological inspections and tests necessary. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-
5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
ARTICLE G. FOOD REFRIGERATION LOCKER PLANTS
3-1G-1: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 107/470
All persons conducting or operating a food refrigeration locker plant in the city, whether licensed under this chapter or under some other chapter of this
code, shall comply strictly with all the regulations of this article and with all the applicable regulations of this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1G-2: BUILDING REGULATIONS:
A. General: No food refrigeration locker plant shall be operated or conducted in a building which is not constructed in full compliance with the building and
zoning regulations of the city. No such plant shall be operated in any frame building, nor in any building the floors of which are not so constructed as to
bear a live load of one hundred fifty (150) pounds per square foot.
B. Wiring: The wiring of every food refrigeration locker plant shall conform to the regulations of the city relative to electric wiring and to the installation of
refrigeration units.
C. Premises: All premises used for the operation of a food refrigeration locker plant shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be thoroughly
cleaned of all refuse, dust and debris at least once in every twenty four (24) hours. It shall be unlawful to store or keep in such plants any
unwholesome, spoiled, contaminated or adulterated food. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1G-3: TEMPERATURE REQUIREMENTS:
No food shall be stored in any food refrigeration locker plant unless such food has been frozen to a temperature of zero degrees Fahrenheit (0F) or below
before being so stored. The lockers or compartments used for the refrigerated storage of food must be kept at all times at a temperature of below fifteen
degrees Fahrenheit (-15F). (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1G-4: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAWS:
No license shall be issued for any food refrigeration locker plant which does not comply with the laws of the state pertaining thereto, and if the health
inspector discovers that a licensed food refrigeration locker plant does not so comply, the license shall be revoked at once. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd.
Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-1G-5: INSPECTIONS:
The health inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as he deems necessary every food refrigeration locker plant in the city to determine
whether all applicable provisions of the ordinances of the city are being complied with. Such inspection shall be made in accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
ARTICLE H. FOOD VENDING MACHINES
3-1H-1: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
All persons licensed hereunder to install, keep, maintain or use an automatic food vending machine whether licensed under this chapter or under another
chapter of this code, shall comply strictly with all the regulations of this article and all applicable regulations of this chapter, except that no lavatory or toilet
facilities or clothing storage areas need be provided where employees in food contact activities are not present for more than one hour a day. (Ord. 0-77-
13, 5-2-1977)
3-1H-2: OPERATOR'S PLACE OF BUSINESS:
A. The city clerk shall be notified of any change in the address of his place of business, and the current address along with the operator's name shall be
indicated in some conspicuous place on each of the machines.
B. In addition, there shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each machine the name, address and telephone number of the person responsible for the
maintenance of such machine. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1H-3: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
No automatic food vending machine shall be located in any premises that exposes the food to danger from improper handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or
other contamination. No automatic food vending machine shall be installed or kept in any toilet or washroom. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977)
3-1H-4: INSPECTIONS:
The health inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as he deems necessary every automatic food vending machine and automatic food
vending machine operation located and conducted in the city to determine whether all applicable provisions of the ordinances of the city are being
complied with. Such investigation shall be made in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 0-77-13, 5-2-1977; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)

Chapter 2
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meanings given herein:
ASHES: The residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible materials.
GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind.
PROPERLY CONSTRUCTED COMPOST HEAP: Pile of mostly organic matter meant to be decayed and used for fertilizing and conditioning land. A
properly constructed compost heap will not produce obnoxious odors or be an attraction to rats or other vermin or rodents.
REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar
materials.
RUBBISH: Nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes), consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans,
yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-14, 5-16-1977)
3-2-2: PROHIBITED ACCUMULATIONS:
A. Uncovered Garbage: It shall be unlawful for any person to place or permit to remain anywhere in the City any garbage or other materials subject to
decay other than leaves or grass, excepting in a tightly covered metal or heavy-duty plastic container.
B. Windblown Refuse: It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit to accumulate any dust or refuse of such a material that it can be blown away
by the wind anywhere in the City except in a covered container.
C. Deposits On Streets: It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any refuse on any public street or alley in the City;
provided, that this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit placing refuse in a container complying with the provisions of this Chapter preparatory
to having such material collected and disposed of in the manner provided herein. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-14, 5-16-1977)
D. Consent Of Owner: It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place any refuse on any premises in the City without the consent of the owner of such
premises.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 109/470
E. Violations; Penalties: Any person violating any provision of this Section shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Failure to pay this
fine within ten (10) days will result in an additional penalty of two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 0-97-84, 12-15-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
3-2-3: DUTY TO PROVIDE REFUSE CONTAINERS:
Refuse containers shall be provided by the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant in charge of all premises within the city and who at all times shall maintain in
good order and repair, one or more receptacles for garbage, waste, ashes and refuse of an aggregate capacity to contain the accumulation from said
premises for at least seven (7) days. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-14, 5-16-1977)
3-2-4: DISPOSAL OF REFUSE:
The owner, tenant, lessee or occupant in charge of any premises in the city shall cause all garbage, waste, ashes and refuse to be removed from said
premises at least once every seven (7) days, except for properly constructed compost heaps. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-14, 5-16-1977)
3-2-5: LOCATION OF CONTAINERS:
No refuse of any kind or refuse containers shall be placed in any front yard as defined by the zoning regulations applicable to the city, except when placed
in such location for collection. In no event shall such refuse or refuse containers be placed in the front yard earlier than the evening preceding the day of
collection. After collection, refuse containers shall be removed from the front yard not later than the evening of said day of collection. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-
1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-14, 5-16-1977)
3-2-6: REMOVAL OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
A. Notice To Remove: It shall be the duty of the health inspector of the city to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner, tenant, lessee or
occupant in charge of any premises to remove any garbage, debris or refuse from such premises when such garbage, debris or refuse is allowed to
gather in violation of this chapter, and to demand the abatement of the violation within ten (10) days.
B. Removal By City: If the person so served with notice does not remove such garbage, debris or refuse, the health inspector may proceed to cause the
removal of such garbage, debris or refuse, keeping an account of the expense thereof, and such expense shall be charged to and paid by said person.
C. Lien: The cost of the removal of such garbage, debris and refuse shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all subsequent liens and
encumbrances, except tax liens, if within sixty (60) days after such costs and expense is incurred by the city, or person performing the service by
authority of the city, a notice of lien is filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook County or in the office of the registrar of titles of Cook County if
the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens system. The health inspector may cause such notice to be filed, and said notice shall consist of
a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, 2) the amount of money representing the cost and
expense incurred or payable for the service, and 3) the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the city. Upon payment of the cost
and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the city or person in
whose name the lien has been filed and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing the notice of lien. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord.
0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
D. Foreclosure Of Lien: The lien provided for in this section may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in cases of mortgages or mechanic's liens.
Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within two (2) years after the date of filing the notice of lien. (Ord. 0-77-5, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-14,
5-16-1977)
3-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 0-94-16, 4-4-
1994)
Chapter 3
NUISANCES
3-3-1: COMMON LAW AND STATUTORY NUISANCES:
In all cases where no provision is herein made defining what are nuisances and how the same may be removed, abated, or prevented, in addition to what
may be declared such herein, those offenses which are known to the common law of the land and in the statutes of the State as nuisances may, in case
the same exist within the City, be treated as such and proceeded against as provided by law1. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-2: HEALTH NUISANCES:
No building, vehicle, structure, receptacle, yard, lot, premises or part thereof, shall be made, used, kept, maintained, or operated in the City if such use,
keeping, maintaining, or operating shall be the occasion of any nuisance, or shall be dangerous to life or detrimental to health.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 110/470
Every building or structure constructed or maintained in violation of the building ordinances of the City2, or which is in an unsanitary condition, or in an
unsafe or dangerous condition, or which in any manner endangers the health or safety of any person or persons, is hereby declared to be a public
nuisance. Every building or part thereof which is in an unsanitary condition by reason of the basement or cellar being covered with stagnant water, or by
reason of the presence of sewer gas, or by reason of any portion of a building being infected with disease or being unfit for human habitation, or which by
reason of any other unsanitary condition, is a source of sickness, or which endangers the public health, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (Ord.
0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-3: OFFENSIVE MATTER AND ODORS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner, agent, occupant or person in control of any lot, building, structure, premises or place within the City to permit or allow the
contents of any tub, or of any receptacle, cesspool, privy, catch basin, vault, sink, water closet, cistern or anything in any room, excavation, vat, building,
premises or place to become a nuisance or offensive so as to be dangerous or prejudicial to health or to become foul, or emit odors prejudicial to public
health. Any act or condition violating this Section is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-4: WATER POLLUTION:
A. Watercourses: It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the City.
B. Stagnant Water: Any stagnant water or pool of stagnant water in the City is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Swimming pools are hereby exempted
from this Section. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-5: ABANDONMENT OF REFRIGERATORS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or discard in any place accessible to children any refrigerator, icebox or ice chest of a capacity of one and
one-half (11/2) cubic feet or more which has an attached lid or door which may be opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch. It shall be
unlawful for any person being the owner, lessee or manager of any place or premises to knowingly permit such abandoned or discarded refrigerator,
icebox or ice chest to remain there in such condition. Any act or condition maintained in violation of this Section is hereby declared to be a public
nuisance3. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-6: CEMETERIES:
It shall be unlawful to establish cemeteries or a cemetery within the City limits without a permit therefor from the City Council; and it shall be unlawful to
bury any person within the City except in an established cemetery. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-7: OFFENSIVE PREMISES:
Any factory, yard, building or structure of any kind, or any tallow chandler's shop, soap factory, tannery, distillery, livery stable, cattle yard or shed, barn,
packinghouse, slaughterhouse or rendering establishment which shall become nauseous, foul or offensive, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 0-
77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-8: AIR POLLUTION:
A. Dense Smoke: It shall be unlawful within the City for any person, owner, agent or operator to permit to cause, suffer or allow the emission of any smoke
from any source whatever of a density, shade or opacity equal to or greater than that described as Number 2 on the Ringelmann Chart as proposed by
the United States Bureau of Mines; provided, that the following exceptions to the provisions of this Section shall be permitted for fuel burning,
combustion or process equipment:
1. For a period or periods aggregating four (4) minutes in any thirty (30) minutes of a density, shade or opacity equal to but not greater than that
described as Number 2 on the Ringelmann Chart.
2. For a period or periods aggregating four (4) minutes in any sixty (60) minutes of a density, shade or opacity equal to but not greater than that
described as Number 2 on the Ringelmann Chart when building a new fire.
B. Control Of Soot, Cinders, Fly Ash, Dust, Noxious Acids, Fumes And Gases: It shall be unlawful for any person in the City or within one-half (1/2) mile of
the corporate limits thereof to permit or cause the escape of such quantities of soot, cinders, fly ash, dust, noxious acids, fumes or gases, or a
combination of any two (2) or more thereof, in such place or manner as to be detrimental to any person or to the public or to endanger the health,
comfort and safety of any such person or of the public, or in such manner as to cause or have a tendency to cause injury or damage to property or
business. The escape of such matter is declared to be a nuisance and may be summarily abated by the City Council, or by anyone whom the corporate
authorities may designate for such purpose. Provided further that fly ash or dust shall not exceed eighty-three hundredths (0.83) pounds per one
thousand (1,000) pounds of gas of which not to exceed five (5) pounds per one thousand (1,000) pounds shall be of such size as to be retained in a
325 mesh United States Standard. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-9: DRINKING CUPS:
It shall be unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup, dipper or other similar utensil for the use of more than one person in any public hall, theater,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 111/470
store or other place frequented by the public. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-10: DEPOSITS OF OBJECTIONABLE SUBSTANCES:
No person shall cast, drop or throw any object, missile or any other substance or article in, from or into any public place thereby littering such public place
or which would jeopardize the health, safety or property of others. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-11: SPOTLIGHTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, maintain or permit the operation of any spotlights which are directed in such manner as to shine upon the
premises of another without such other person's express consent. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-12: BUG KILLER LIGHTS AND DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, maintain or cause to be operated on any premises within the City any bug killer lights and other bug killing
mechanical devices between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-13: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES:
The Building Official and members of the Police Department serving the City are hereby authorized to abate any nuisance existing in the City, whether
such nuisance is one specifically recognized by ordinance or not. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
3-3-14: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) for a first offense; not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) for a second offense; and not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for every offense thereafter, and in no event shall such person be fined in excess of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any such offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs
or continues. (Ord. 0-77-18, 6-7-1977)
Chapter 4
RAT CONTROL
3-4-1: RAT STOPPAGE REQUIRED; DEFINITIONS:
Every building or structure within the city shall be rat stopped, freed of rats and maintained in a rat stopped and rat free condition. For purposes of this
chapter, the following terms shall have the definitions herein ascribed to them:
HARDWARE CLOTH: Wire screen of such thickness and spacings as to afford reasonable protection against the entrance of rats.
RAT HARBORAGE: Any condition which provides shelter or protection for rats, thus favoring their multiplication and continued existence in, under or
outside a structure of any kind.
RAT STOPPAGE: Applies to a form of ratproofing to prevent the ingress of rats into or under buildings or other structures from the exterior or from one
building or structure to another. It consists essentially of the closing of all openings in the exterior walls, ground or first floors, basements and foundations,
that may be reached by rats from the ground by climbing or by burrowing, with concrete, sheet iron, hardware cloth, or other types of ratproofing material
impervious to rat gnawing, approved by the health inspector. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977; Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-
2005)
3-4-2: INSPECTION; NOTICE:
It shall be the duty of the health inspector to cause inspections of the interior and exterior of buildings or other structures to determine evidence of rat
infestation and the existence of new breaks or leaks in the rat stoppage, and when any evidence is found indicating the presence of rats or openings
through which rats may enter such buildings or structures, to serve or cause to be served the owner, agent or occupant of such building or structure with
written notice to abate the conditions found. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977; Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-4-3: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
A. Maintenance: The owner, agent or occupant in charge of any building or structure shall maintain it in a rat stopped condition and repair all breaks or
leaks that may occur in the rat stoppage.
B. Unlawful To Remove Rat Stoppage: It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, contractor, public utility company, plumber, or any other person to
remove the rat stoppage from any building or structure for any purpose and fail to restore the same in satisfactory condition, or to make any new
openings that are not closed or sealed against the entrance of rats. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 112/470
C. Structural Changes: Whenever conditions inside or under any building or structure provide such extensive harborage for rats that the health inspector
deems it necessary to eliminate such harborage, he may require the owner or occupant in charge of any such building or structure to install suitable
cement floors and basements, or to require such owner or occupant to correct such rat harborage as may be necessary in order to facilitate the
eradication of rats. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977; Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
D. Dumping Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to place, leave, dump or permit to accumulate any garbage, trash or refuse in any building,
structure or premises so that the same shall afford food or harborage for rats, or to dump or place on any premises, land or waterway any dead animals
or waste vegetable or animal matter of any kind, except for properly constructed compost heaps. For the purpose of this chapter, a "properly
constructed compost heap" shall mean pile of mostly organic matter meant to be decayed and used for fertilizing and conditioning land. A properly
constructed compost heap will not produce obnoxious odors or be an attraction to rats or other vermin or rodents1.
E. Accumulations Of Materials Or Junk: It shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate or permit the accumulation on any open lot or other premises,
any lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stones, scrap metal, motor vehicle bodies or parts or similar materials, rubbish or any articles of junk unless the
same shall be evenly piled or stacked. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977)
3-4-4: RAT STOPPAGE BY OWNER; NOTICE:
Upon receipt of notice in writing from the health inspector, the owner, agent or occupant in charge of any building, structure or premises specified in such
notice shall take immediate measures for the rat stoppage of such building or structure and for freeing the premises of all rats, and unless said work is
completed in the specified time in the notice, in no event to be less than ten (10) days, or any written extension thereof that may be granted by the health
inspector, then the owner, agent or occupant in charge of said building, structure or premises shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter.
Whenever the owner, agent or occupant in charge of any building, structure or premises, after being served with notices provided in this section, has failed
within the time fixed in the notice to perform all work necessary to prevent the ingress of rats to said building or structure or to exterminate rats from the
premises described in said notice, the health inspector or person duly authorized by him may provide for the extermination of rats and do such work as is
necessary to free said premises from rats and to maintain said premises in a rat stopped condition. The health inspector may charge to and collect from
the owner, agent or occupant in charge of any building, structure or premises the reasonable cost and expense of preventing such ingress of rats to their
property and of rat extermination therein, after notice to such owner or owners, or persons as provided by this chapter, and failure of such owners or
persons to comply. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977; Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-4-5: LIEN ON PREMISES:
The cost and expense of rat stoppage and extermination is a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax
liens, if within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred by the city, or person performing the service by authority of the city, a notice of lien is
filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook County or in the office of the registrar of titles of Cook County if the real estate affected is registered
under the Torrens system. The health inspector may cause such notice of lien to be filed, and said notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: a)
a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; b) the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the
service; and c) the date or dates when such cost and expense were incurred by the municipality. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of
or person interested in the property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed
and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-16-1977; Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005,
eff. 7-17-2005)
3-4-6: FORECLOSURE OF LIEN:
The lien provided for in this chapter may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or mechanic's liens as is provided by
statute. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within one year after the date of filing notice of lien. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-
16-1977)
3-4-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day upon which it continues to occur. (Ord. 0-77-6, 3-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-77-15, 5-
16-1977)
Chapter 5
NOISE CONTROL
3-5-1: PROHIBITED CONDITIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessary or unusually loud noise or any noise
which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others, within the limits of the City. Airport facilities and
aircraft be and are hereby exempted from the terms of this Chapter. (Ord. 0-77-20, 6-7-1977)
3-5-2: NOISE STANDARDS:
The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this Chapter, but said enumeration shall not
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 113/470
be deemed to be exclusive:
A. Horns, Signaling Devices: The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, or other vehicle on any street or public place of
the City, except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sounds; and the sounding
of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. The use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity;
the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held
up. This paragraph shall not apply to approved signaling or sound devices used by licensed street vendors.
B. Radios, Phonographs: The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio or television receiving set, musical instrument,
phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the
neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume that is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room,
vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument,
phonograph, machine or device between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. in such a manner as to be plainly audible
at a distance of thirty feet (30') from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this Section.
C. Power Lawn Mowers: The use and operation of power lawn mowers between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. within
or adjacent to areas used for residential purposes.
D. Loud Speakers, Amplifiers For Advertising: The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any radio receiving set, musical
instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the
public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. This paragraph shall not
apply to political announcements.
E. Yelling, Shouting: Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in
any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other types of residences, or of any person in the vicinity.
F. Animals, Birds: The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons
in the vicinity.
G. Steam Whistles: The blowing of any locomotive steam whistle or steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to
begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper City authorities.
H. Exhausts: The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor boat, or motor vehicle
except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom.
I. Defect In Vehicle Or Load: The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in such manner as to create loud and
unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise.
J. Loading, Unloading, Opening Boxes: The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and
destruction of bails, boxes, crates and containers. (Ord. 0-77-20, 6-7-1977)
K. Construction Or Repair Of Buildings: The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building other than between the hours of
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on weekdays or Saturday, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and
safety, and then only with a permit from the Building Official, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three (3) days or less while the
emergency continues, and which permit may be renewed for periods of three (3) days or less while the emergency continues. If the Building Official
shall determine that the public health and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building or the excavation of
streets and highways within the prohibited hours, and if he shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest, he
may grant written permission for such work to be done upon application being made at the time the permit for the work is awarded or during the
progress of the work. The prohibition contained in this subsection shall not apply to minor erection, demolition, alteration or repair, which work can be
completed within a period of one hour nor shall it apply to volunteer labor between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
(Ord. 0-88-52, 10-3-1988)
L. Schools, Courts, Churches, Hospitals: The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court
while the same is in use, or adjacent to any hospital which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly
annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital or court street.
M. Hawkers, Peddlers: The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood.
N. Drums: The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale.
O. Transportation Of Metal Rails, Pillars And Columns: The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material, over and along streets
and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to disturb the peace and quiet of
such streets or public places.
P. Pile Drivers, Hammers: The operation between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of any pile driver, steam shovel,
pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist, or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise, unless the Building
Official determines that the usage is necessary during such hours.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 114/470
Q. Blowers: The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the
explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient
to deaden such noise. (Ord. 0-77-20, 6-7-1977)
3-5-3: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). Each hour during which a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 0-77-20, 6-7-1977)
Chapter 6
PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY CODE1
(Rep. by Ord. 0-88-48, 10-3-1988)
Chapter 7
PROPERTY RENTAL CODE
3-7-1: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
Every person, individual, firm, owner, corporation or landlord or combination thereof engaged in the business of leasing or renting any apartment building,
multiple-unit, multiple dwelling, dwelling or dwelling units is hereby required to make application to and receive an annual license from the city before
engaging or continuing in such business. The application shall be accompanied by a twenty five dollar ($25.00) annual license fee for each commercial
space leased, rented or to be rented. An application for a license required by this chapter shall be made in conformance with section 2-1-2 of this code.
The city shall issue said license if the following conditions are met:
A. Code Compliance: The applicant's property is not in violation of any ordinance of the city.
B. Designation Of Agent: No operating license shall be issued or renewed for an applicant unless such applicant has first designated an agent for the
receipt of service of complaints for violations of the provisions of this chapter or code and for service of process pursuant thereto when said applicant is
absent from his or her normal place of business. Such a designation shall be made in writing, and shall accompany each application form.
C. Renewal Of License: An application for renewal of an operating license shall be made thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the current operating
license. An application form shall be mailed to owner at least forty five (45) days prior to the expiration of the current operating license.
D. Notice Of Change In Ownership: Every person holding an operating license shall give notice in writing to the building official within ten (10) days after
having transferred or otherwise disposed of legal control of any licensed apartment building, multiple unit, multiple dwelling, dwelling or dwelling units.
Such notice shall include the name and address of the person or persons succeeding to the ownership or control of such apartment building, multiple
unit, multiple dwelling, dwelling or dwelling units.
E. Term Of License: Every license shall be in effect for the current fiscal year (May 1 _ April 30) unless sooner revoked for cause by the city. (Ord. 0-01-35,
12-17-2001, eff. 12-27-2001)
3-7-2: INSPECTIONS:
All one-family and two-family dwelling units, which are rented or leased, or are intended to be rented or leased, all multi-family dwelling units which are
rented or leased or are intended to be rented or leased, and all boarding or lodging houses shall be inspected annually by a city inspector. Fees for such
inspections or reinspections shall be paid by the property owner or landlord prior to the performance of said inspection or reinspection. The fees shall be
levied as set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 0-04-28, 6-21-2004, eff. 7-1-2004)
3-7-3: INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
The building official shall cause the health inspector, enforcement officer or such other appropriate authority as he may designate to make annual
inspections to which an applicant for a license or licenses shall consent, to determine the health and safety conditions of the apartment buildings, multiple
dwellings, rooming houses, dwelling or dwelling units within the city. For the purpose of making such inspections the health inspector, enforcement officer
or the appointed public official shall request permission from the licensee to enter, examine and survey at any reasonable time all apartment buildings,
multiple dwellings, rooming houses, dwelling or dwelling units. (Ord. 0-01-35, 12-17-2001, eff. 12-27-2001; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
If the tenant or person in charge of an apartment building, or a commercial building, multiple dwelling, rooming house, dwelling or dwelling unit shall refuse
such permission to the health inspector, enforcement officer and/or designated official, the city administrator is hereby authorized to seek a warrant from a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 115/470
court of competent jurisdiction to enter the premises and conduct said inspection. Permission by tenant or person in charge to enter the premises is
interpreted as free access to the leased portion of the premises or central facilities serving the premises for the purpose of such inspection, examination
and survey. (Ord. 0-87-26, 8-17-1987; amd. Ord. 0-05-23, 7-5-2005, eff. 7-17-2005)
3-7-4: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license or permit may be revoked by the city council during the life of such license or permit for the violation by the licensee or permittee of any
ordinance provisions relating to the license or permit, the subject of the license or permit, or the premises occupied; such revocation may be in addition to
any fine imposed. This section shall not apply to any license or permit for which a specific procedure for revocation of such license or permit is provided by
another ordinance of the city. (Ord. 0-87-26, 8-17-1987)
3-7-5: NOTICE OF REVOCATION AND HEARING:
The city administrator shall cause notice of the revocation of the license to be served on the licensee either personally or by certified United States mail
and the reason or reasons therefor and such licensee may within ten (10) days of the date of such notice, petition the mayor and city council for a hearing
on restoration of license under such conditions as the mayor and city council may deem necessary for the correction of conditions set forth in the
revocation notice. (Ord. 0-87-26, 8-17-1987)
3-7-6: INSPECTION FEES:
