10-7-16: STOP BEFORE EMERGING FROM ALLEY, PRIVATE DRIVE:
A. The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into the
sidewalk area extending across any alleyway or driveway and shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision, and
upon entering the roadway shall yield the right of way to all vehicles approaching on said roadway.
B. No driver shall drive any vehicle within any sidewalk area except at permanent or temporary driveways or alleys nor upon any portion of the roadway
marked as a safety zone. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-17: STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING MOVEMENTS:
A. Upon any street or highway, no person shall stop, park or leave standing any vehicle whether attended or unattended, upon the paved or main traveled
part of the street or highway when it is practical to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off such part of said street or highway, but in every event a clear
and unobstructed width of the street or highway opposite such standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and a clear view of
such stopped vehicle shall be available from a distance of two hundred feet (200') in each direction upon such street or highway.
B. This section shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle which is disabled while on the paved or main traveled portion of a street or highway in such
manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving such disabled vehicle in such position. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-
1977)
C. At any time, it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stop, stand or park any vehicle in any of the following locations:
Prospect Court from Olive Street southerly to the end of the street. (Ord. 0-03-31, 8-18-2003, eff. 8-28-2003)
10-7-18: ILLEGALLY STOPPED VEHICLES; REMOVAL:
(Rep. by Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-7-19: ABANDONED VEHICLES:
(Rep. by Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-7-20: INOPERABLE VEHICLES:
It is hereby declared that all inoperable motor vehicles, whether on public or private property, are a public nuisance. Any person who shall fail to dispose of
any inoperable motor vehicle under his control, upon receipt of a notice from the city, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense.
However, nothing in this section shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use, to historical vehicles over twenty five (25)
years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles.
As used in this section, "inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least six (6) months, the engine, wheels or other
parts have been removed, or upon which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is
incapable of being driven under its own motor power. "Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily
incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-21: LIMITATIONS ON BACKING, U-TURNS:
The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. No
vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety without backing into traffic or
interfering with traffic. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to make a U-turn at places where posted signs indicate that such turns are
prohibited. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-22: MISCELLANEOUS TRAFFIC CONTROL:
A. The driver of any vehicle other than public safety vehicles shall not exit from Court Alley to southbound Elmhurst Road (Route 83).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 390/470
B. There shall be placed a "Local Traffic Only" sign on the east side of School Street immediately north of its intersection with Palatine Road. The sign
shall be placed in such exact location as to allow visibility for motorists driving north on School Street from Palatine Road in the determination of the
city engineer. (Ord. 0-08-21, 6-2-2008)
10-7-23: RIDING ON MOTORCYCLES AND BICYCLES:
A person operating a motorcycle or bicycle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, and such operators shall not carry any
other person nor shall any other person ride on a bicycle or motorcycle unless such bicycle or motorcycle is designed to carry more than one person, in
which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for two (2) persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the rear or
side of the operator. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-24: OBSTRUCTION TO DRIVER'S VIEW OR OPERATION:
A. No person shall drive a vehicle when it is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat such number of persons, exceeding three (3), as to obstruct the
view of the driver to the front or sides of the vehicle or as to interfere with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle.
B. No passenger in a vehicle shall ride in such position as to interfere with the driver's view ahead or to the sides, or to interfere with his control over the
driving mechanism of the vehicle. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-25: COASTING PROHIBITED:
A. The driver of any motor vehicle when traveling upon a downgrade shall not coast with the gears of such vehicle in neutral.
B. The driver of a motor vehicle of the second division as defined in this title, when traveling upon a downgrade, shall not coast with the clutch disengaged.
(Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-26: FOLLOWING FIRE APPARATUS; CROSSING FIRE HOSE:
A. The driver of any vehicle other than one on official business shall not follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than five
hundred feet (500') or drive into or park such vehicle within the block where fire apparatus is stopped in answer to a fire alarm.
B. No vehicle shall be driven over an unprotected hose of a Fire Department when laid down on any street or private driveway to be used at any fire or
alarm of fire, without the consent of the Fire Department official in command. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-27: DEPOSITS OF INJURIOUS MATERIALS:
No person shall throw or deposit upon any street or highway any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, or any other substance likely to injure any
person, animal or vehicle upon such street or highway.
Any person who drops or permits to be dropped or thrown upon any street or highway any destructive or injurious material shall immediately remove the
same or cause it to be removed.
Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street or highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street
or highway from such vehicle. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-28: APPROACHING, OVERTAKING AND PASSING SCHOOL BUS:
A. The driver of a vehicle upon any street or highway in this City upon meeting or overtaking from either direction, any school bus which has stopped on
the street or highway for the purpose of receiving or discharging any school children, shall stop the vehicle before reaching such school bus, when
there is in operation on said school bus a visual signal as required by law, and said driver shall not proceed until such school bus resumes motion or is
signaled by the school bus driver to proceed, or the visual signals are no longer actuated.
B. Every bus used for the transportation of school children shall bear upon the front and rear thereof plainly visible signs containing the words "school bus"
in letters not less than eight inches (8") in height, and in addition shall be equipped with visual signals which shall be actuated by the driver of said
school bus whenever the brakes are applied.
C. The driver of a vehicle upon a street or highway of which the roadways for traffic moving in opposite directions are separated by a strip of ground which
is not surfaced or suitable for vehicular traffic, need not stop his vehicle upon meeting or passing a school bus which is on the opposite roadway; and
need not stop his vehicle when driving upon a controlled access highway when a school bus is stopped in a loading zone adjacent to the surface or
improved part of a controlled access highway where pedestrians are not permitted to cross such controlled access highway. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-29: TRAVEL ON CERTAIN ROADS RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, to travel or be upon that part of Robert Avenue from a line ten feet (10') west of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.

It shall also be unlawful for any truck to travel eastbound on that portion of Old Willow Road extending from Wolf Road to Mandel Lane; provided, however,

10-7-30: OBSTRUCTING PERSON ON STREETS OR HIGHWAYS:
Any person who shall wilfully and unnecessarily hinder, obstruct or delay, or who shall wilfully and unnecessarily attempt to delay, hinder or obstruct any
other person in lawfully driving or traveling along or upon any street or highway or who shall offer for barter or sale merchandise on said street or highway
so as to interfere with the effective movement of traffic shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-31: FARM VEHICLES REGULATED:
No person shall operate a farm tractor on a street or highway unless such tractor is being used as an implement of husbandry in connection with farming
operations.
For the purpose of this Section, use of a farm tractor as an implement of husbandry in connection with farming operations shall be deemed to include use
of such tractor in connection with the transportation of agricultural products and of farm machinery, equipment and supplies as well as transportation of
such tractors in connection with the obtaining of repairs thereto. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-32: UNATTENDED ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful to leave any horse or other draft animal unattended in any street or highway without having such animal securely fastened. (Ord. 0-77-
17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-33: CLINGING TO VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person on any street riding a bicycle, motorcycle or toy vehicle to cling to or to attach himself or his vehicle to any moving
vehicle, or any person operating a moving motor vehicle to permit any other person to make such attachment. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-34: TOY VEHICLES IN ROADWAYS:
It shall be unlawful for any person upon ice or roller skates, coasters, sleds or other toy vehicles to go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. (Ord.
0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-35: RIDING ON RUNNING BOARDS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, running boards or outside steps of any vehicle. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-36: PROCESSIONS; FUNERALS:
A. No person shall drive any vehicle between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such
vehicles are conspicuously designated, as required in this section. This provision shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles when responding to
emergency calls.
B. Each driver in a funeral or other authorized procession shall drive as near to the right edge of the roadway as is practical and shall follow the vehicle
ahead as close as is safe and practical.
C. Each vehicle comprising a funeral or other authorized procession shall be identified by the display of a pennant outside the vehicle or by a suitable
decalcomania sticker or card placed upon the right hand windshield in a prominent place, but not so as to obstruct the driver's view. The headlights of
each vehicle comprising a funeral or other authorized procession shall be lighted, in addition to the foregoing. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-37: QUIET ZONES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sound a horn or warning device of any vehicle, except in case of emergency or to race a motor or to make any
unnecessary noise in areas designated as quiet zones. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-7-38: YIELD RIGHT OF WAY INTERSECTIONS:
The driver of a vehicle in obedience to a yield right of way sign shall reduce the speed of his vehicle to not more than twenty (20) miles per hour and shall
yield the right of way to other vehicles which have entered the intersecting street, either from the right or left, or which are approaching so closely to such
intersection as to constitute a hazard; but said driver having so yielded may proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 392/470
If a driver is involved in a collision at an intersection or interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a yield right of way sign, such
collision shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the driver's failure to yield right of way.
The following entrances to intersections are hereby designated as yield right of way entrances:
Brook Road, southeast entrance at the intersection of Compton Lane, Maple Lane, and Brook Road.
Clarendon Street, eastbound and westbound at Maple Street.
Clarendon Street, eastbound and westbound at Owen Street.

Club Village Traffic Regulations" on file at the city offices.
South Parkway, eastbound and westbound at Elm Street. (Ord. 0-12-41, 11-13-2012)
10-7-39: NO RIGHT TURN INTERSECTIONS:
A. Except as provided in subsection B of this section, vehicular traffic facing a steady circular red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop sign, but
if there is no such stop sign, before entering the crosswalk on the nearest side of the intersection, or if there is no such crosswalk, then before entering
the intersection, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown.
B. Except where a sign is in place prohibiting a turn and the city council by ordinance or the state by rule or regulation prohibits any such turn, vehicular
traffic facing any steady red signal may cautiously enter the intersection to turn right, or to turn left from a one-way street into a one-way street, after
stopping as required in subsection A of this section. After stopping, the driver shall yield the right of way to any vehicle in the intersection or
approaching on another roadway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time such driver is moving across or within the intersection
or junction or roadways. Such driver shall yield the right of way to pedestrians within the intersection or an adjacent sidewalk.
C. The following entrances to intersections be and are hereby declared to be no right turn entrances and signs shall be posted accordingly; provided,
however, that this provision shall apply only during the hours of three o'clock (3:00) P.M. through seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. as stipulated on the posted
signs:
Euclid Avenue, westbound entrance to northbound Chester Lane
Euclid Avenue, westbound entrance to northbound Maple Lane
Euclid Avenue, westbound entrance to northbound School Lane
D. Prohibit right turn off of Burning Bush Lane onto Piper Lane except for emergency vehicle use only.
E. No right turn from southbound Wheeling Road to westbound Clarendon Street from the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
and from three o'clock (3:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. (Ord. 0-13-21, 10-28-2013)

10-7-42: SKATEBOARDS PROHIBITED:
A. Definition: For the purpose of this section a "skateboard" is defined as a board or other horizontal surface having attached thereto wheels and which is
operated or steered by the use of an individual's limbs.
B. Prohibited: No person shall operate a skateboard upon any private street, parking lot or other area open to the public within any area zoned as a
business district under the zoning ordinance of the city or upon any street, sidewalk or other open space within any area owned by the city and
designated as a "no skateboard area". (Ord. 0-98-01, 1-20-1998, eff. 1-30-1998)
C. Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined no less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Any
person cited under the provisions of this section not paying the fine within ten (10) days shall face an additional penalty of not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 0-16-19, 6-13-2016)
10-7-43: LOITERING:
A. Streets, Public Areas: It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or encumber any street corner or other public place in the city by lounging in or
about the same, after being directed to move on by any police officer and/or community service officer.
B. Commuter Stations, Parking Lots: It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter or lounge about at any time at the commuter station located at 55 South
Wolf Road or to loiter at any time in the commuter parking lot located adjacent to 55 South Wolf Road. (Ord. 0-98-02, 1-20-1998, eff. 1-30-1998)
C. Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Any
person cited under the provisions of this section not paying the fine within ten (10) days shall face an additional penalty of not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 0-16-19, 6-13-2016)

Chapter 8
PARKING REGULATIONS
10-8-1: NO PARKING PLACES:
At any time, it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in
compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device: (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
A. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to stand in an intersection, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the
directions of a police officer or traffic control device. Any person violating the provision of this subsection shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Failure to pay this fine within ten (10) days shall result in an additional penalty
of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
B. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to stand in a crosswalk, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions
of a police officer or traffic control device. Any person violating the provision of this subsection shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Failure to pay this fine within ten (10) days shall result in an additional penalty of not
less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 0-16-19, 6-13-2016)
C. Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or tunnel or the approach thereto.
D. Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or edge of street immediately opposite the end of a safety zone. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
E. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to stand within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal on the approaching side, except when necessary to avoid conflict with
other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device. Any person violating the provision of this subsection shall be
fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Failure to pay this fine within ten (10)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 394/470
days shall result in an additional penalty of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 0-16-19,
6-13-2016)
F. Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection or crosswalk.
G. Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
H. Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing.
I. Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy five
feet (75') of said entrance when properly signed posted. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
J. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to stand either alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking would obstruct traffic,
except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device. Any person
violating the provision of this subsection shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense. Failure to pay this fine within ten (10) days shall result in an additional penalty of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 0-16-19, 6-13-2016)
K. On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a street.
L. At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
M. At any place where official signs prohibit parking. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)

Apple Drive, from Milwaukee Avenue westerly to Burning Bush Drive at any time except on the south side between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays during the months of April through October.

Center.

10-8-1-1: RESERVED:
(Ord. 0-15-06, 2-9-2015)
10-8-2: PARKING AT CURB OR EDGE OF ROAD:
No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to the curb edge of pavement, except on one-way streets, and it shall be unlawful to stand
or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel with the curb or edge of pavement and with the two (2) right wheels of the vehicle within twelve inches
(12") of the regularly established curb line or edge of pavement, except that upon those streets that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be
parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-8-3: PARKING VEHICLES FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from which
vehicle merchandise is peddled. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-8-4: LOADING ZONES; CAB AND BUS STANDS:
A. Loading Zones: During the time specified herein, it shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer
than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three (3) minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight carrying vehicle for
a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30) minutes, in any of the following places:
1. In any public alley, during any hour of the day or night.
2. At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb or edge of pavement before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time.
3. At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb or edge of roadway before the entrance to a public building between eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. except on Sunday.
B. Cab Stands, Bus Stands: No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as taxicab stands; and no
vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place designated as a bus loading zone. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-8-5: ALL NIGHT PARKING:
In the single-family residential districts, it shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. of any day on any street, except for emergency purposes. In all of the districts, it shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle weighing in
excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds on any street for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any day, except for emergency purposes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 396/470
Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
Any person cited under the provisions of this section not paying the fine within ten (10) days shall face an additional penalty of not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 0-16-19, 6-13-2016)
10-8-6: PARKING IN ALLEYS:
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the
roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the
driveway entrance to any abutting property. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-8-7: ABANDONED, LOST, STOLEN, HAZARDOUS UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
10-8-7-1: STORING, PARKING OR LEAVING ABANDONED, DISMANTLED OR OTHER SUCH MOTOR VEHICLE PROHIBITED;
DECLARED NUISANCE; EXCEPTIONS:
No person shall park, store, leave, or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any motor vehicle of any kind which is in an abandoned, wrecked,
dismantled, inoperative, junked, or partially dismantled condition whether attended or not, upon any public or private property within the City for a period of
time in excess of twenty four (24) hours. The presence of an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, junked or partially dismantled vehicle or parts
thereof, on private or public property is declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. This
Section shall not apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on private property or to any vehicle held in connection with a business enterprise, lawfully
licensed by the City and properly operated in the appropriate business zone, pursuant to the zoning laws of the City. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-2: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
A. Whenever it comes to the attention of the City that any nuisance as defined in Section 10-8-7-1 of this Chapter exists with in the City, a notice in writing
shall be served upon the owner of the vehicle, notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and requesting its removal in the time specified in this
Chapter. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
B. Written notice required under this Section shall be given at least seven (7) days prior to the time of compliance. It shall constitute sufficient notice, when
a copy of same is posted in a conspicuous place upon the vehicle and a copy is sent by registered mail to the registered owner of the vehicle. (Ord. 0-
85-05, 3-4-1985)
C. The notice shall contain the request for removal within the time specified in this Section, and the notice shall advise that upon failure to comply with the
notice to remove, the City or its designee shall undertake such removal with the cost of removal to be levied against the owner of the vehicle. The
notice shall also advise that the recipient has a right to a hearing and it shall advise the recipient of the manner and of the requirements to be met for
securing a hearing. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-3: RESPONSIBILITY FOR REMOVAL:
Upon proper notice and opportunity to be heard, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, or inoperable vehicle shall be responsible for its
removal within seven (7) days of posting the notice on the vehicle or the date of mailing a copy of such notice, whichever is later. In the event of removal
and disposition by the City, the owner of said vehicle shall be liable for the expenses incurred. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-4: REQUEST FOR HEARING:
The persons to whom the notices are directed, or their duly authorized agents may file a written request for hearing before the person in charge of the
Police Department serving the City within the seven (7) day period of compliance prescribed in Section 10-8-7-3 of this Chapter, for the purpose of
defending the charges by the City. Failure to file a request within the specified time shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. A timely request for
a hearing shall cause the removal of the subject vehicle to be delayed pending the decision of the hearing official. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-5: PROCEDURE FOR HEARING:
The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable after the filing of the request and the persons to whom the notices are directed shall be advised of the
time and place of said hearing at least two (2) days in advance thereof. At any such hearing, the persons to whom the notices have been directed may
introduce witnesses and evidence. The City Administrator shall appoint a representative of the City to serve as hearing official. In no case shall the hearing
official be an individual who was involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle. The duties and responsibilities of the hearing official shall be set by
resolution of the City Council. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-6: REMOVAL OF MOTOR VEHICLE FROM PROPERTY:
If the violation described in the notice has not been remedied within the seven (7) day period of compliance, or in the event that after a hearing is duly
held, the violation is affirmed, the Police Department shall have the right to remove the vehicle from the premises. It is unlawful for any person to interfere
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 397/470
with, hinder, or refuse to allow such person or persons to enter upon private property for the purpose of removing a vehicle under the provisions of this
Chapter. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-7: TOWING HAZARDOUS OR UNLAWFUL VEHICLES; OTHER EMERGENCIES:
The Police Department is authorized to immediately remove and tow away or have removed and towed away by commercial towing service, any
hazardous or unlawful vehicle illegally parked in any place where such parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire
hydrant, is determined by the Police Department to be a stolen vehicle, or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle, or show
removal equipment or other equipment performing emergency service. Vehicles so towed away shall be stored on any City property or in a public garage
or parking lot and shall be returned to the owner or operator thereof after payment for applicable expenses incurred by the City in removing and storing
such vehicles. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-8: NOTICE OF REMOVAL:
Within forty eight (48) hours of the removal of a hazardous vehicle, under the provisions of this Chapter, the City shall give notice to the registered owner
of the vehicle, if known, and if the vehicle was removed from private property, also to the current or last known registered owner of the said private
property. The notice shall give the location of where the vehicle or vehicles are stored and the costs incurred by the City for removal. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-
1984)
10-8-7-9: DISPOSAL OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
A. When an abandoned, hazardous, lost, stolen, unlawful or unclaimed vehicle seven (7) years of age or newer remains unclaimed by the registered
owner, lien holder, or the person legally entitled to its possession for a period of thirty (30) days after removal has been effected as provided in Section
10-8-7-8 of this Chapter, the City shall cause it to be sold at public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in
a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the sale on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to
the sale, the Police Department, where the vehicle is impounded, shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to
the registered owner, lien holder and other persons known by the Police Department or towing service to be legally entitled to the possession of the
vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to
reclaim the vehicle.
B. In those instances where the certified notification specified in Section 10-8-7-8 of this Chapter has been returned by the postal authorities to the law
enforcement agency due to the addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from the appropriate state vehicle registration
records, the sending of a second certificate notice will not be required. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-10: DISPOSAL OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES WITHOUT NOTICE:
A. When the identity of the registered owner, lien holder and other person legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, hazardous, lost or unclaimed
vehicle of seven (7) years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided for in this Chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided in
Section 10-8-7-9 of this Chapter without notice when the owner identity cannot be determined.
B. When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is impounded as specified by this Chapter, it will be kept in custody a minimum of ten
(10) days for the purpose of determining the identity of the registered owner, title holder or lien holder by the U.S. mail, public service or in person for a
determination of disposition; and an examination of the State Police stolen vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten (10)
day period, without the benefit of disposition information being received from the registered owner, title holder or the lien holder, the Police Department
may authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk. An exception to the above is provided for, if in the opinion of the police officer processing the vehicle,
it has value of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more and can be restored to safe operating condition. In this event, the Police Department may
authorize its purchase as salvage and the Secretary of State may issue a salvage certificate if the vehicle is bonded in the manner as provided for
certificates or title, under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-100.
C. A vehicle classified as an antique vehicle may however be sold to a person desiring to restore it. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-11: POLICE REPORTS AFTER VEHICLE IS RECLAIMED OR DISPOSED OF:
When a vehicle in the custody of the Police Department is reclaimed by the registered owner, lien holder or other legally entitled person, or when the
vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this Chapter, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the Police Department
for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-12: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS OF SALE OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the City is authorized to be towed and disposed of as set forth in this Chapter, the proceeds of the
public sale or disposition after deduction of towing, storage and processing charges, shall be deposited in the Treasury. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-13: TITLING VEHICLES AFTER PUBLIC SALE; REMOVAL OF LIENS:
When an applicant for a certificate of title under this Chapter presents to the Secretary of State proof that he has purchased or acquired a vehicle at a
public sale as authorized by this Chapter and such fact is certified to by the Police Department, the Secretary of State shall issue a certificate of title for the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 398/470
vehicle upon receipt of the statutory fee and a properly executed application for a certificate of title. The title issued by the Secretary of State under 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-212, shall be free of any lien that existed against the vehicle prior to the time the vehicle was acquired by the applicant under
this Chapter. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-14: RECLAIMING TOWED VEHICLES:
Any time before a vehicle at public sale is disposed of as provided for in this Chapter, the owner, lien holder, or other person legally entitled to its
possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the City proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No vehicle shall be
released under this Section until all towing, storage and administrative charges have been paid. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-15: HAZARDOUS AND UNLAWFUL TOW HEARING:
A. Any person whose vehicle has been towed pursuant to Section 10-8-7-7 of this Chapter shall have the right to request a hearing to contest disposition
of the vehicle or any towing charges or fees incurred.
B. Request for a hearing under this Section shall be made in writing to the City within seven (7) days after receipt of a notice of towing. Failure to file a
request within the time specified shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing.
C. All hearings held pursuant to this Section shall be held on a date convenient to both parties but in no event shall any hearing be scheduled later than
thirty (30) days after the date the request for hearing was filed. No action regarding the disposition of any vehicle or vehicles shall be taken pending the
decision reached in the hearing.
D. All notices sent pursuant to Section 10-8-7-8 of this Chapter, to owners of vehicles towed pursuant to Section 10-8-7-7 of this Chapter, shall advise of
the availability of the hearing process. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-16: FEES FOR TOWING AND STORAGE:
Fees for towing and storage of vehicles covered by this Chapter shall be set by resolution of the City Council. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-7-17: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day a violation of
any at the provisions of this Title exists shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 0-84-27, 11-5-1984)
10-8-8: WILLOW WOODS CONDOMINIUM COMPLEX PARKING REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand or park on that part of the condominium complex parking area depicted on Exhibit B, on file in the City
offices and hereby designated as a fire lane. As used in this Section, the term "fire lane" shall mean a travel lane for firefighting equipment. There shall be
no standing or parking of any motor vehicle at any time upon the fire lane so that firefighting equipment can move freely thereon. Any person violating any
provision of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. The vehicles of violators may be towed by or at the
direction of the city. (Ord. 0-91-06, 4-20-1981)
10-8-9: WILLOW HEIGHTS CONDOMINIUM COMPLEX PARKING REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand or park on that part at the condominium complex parking area depicted on exhibit B, on file in the city
offices and hereby designated as a fire lane. As used in this section, the term "fire lane" shall mean a travel lane for firefighting equipment. There shall be
no standing or parking of any motor vehicle at any time upon the fire lane so that firefighting equipment can move freely thereon. Any person violating any
provision of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues The vehicles of violators may be towed by or at the
direction of the city. (Ord. 0-81-37, 11-16-1981)
10-8-10: ROB ROY COUNTRY CLUB VILLAGE CONDOMINIUM COMPLEX PARKING REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand or park on that part of the condominium complex parking areas depicted on exhibit B entitled "Rob Roy
Country Club Village Traffic Regulations" on file in the city offices and hereby designated as a fire lane. As used in this section, the term "fire lane" shall
mean a travel lane for firefighting equipment. There shall be no standing or parking of any motor vehicle at any time upon the fire lane so that firefighting
equipment can move freely thereon. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues. The vehicles of violators may be towed by or at the direction of the city. (Ord. 0-86-33, 9-15-1986)
10-8-11: WIMBLEDON LAKE ESTATES RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT PARKING REGULATIONS:
A. The city council hereby finds that the facts and statements contained in the preamble to ordinance 0-90-221 are true and correct.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 399/470
B. The city council hereby agrees to enter into an agreement with the Wimbledon Lakes Estates Homeowners' Association for enforcing the city codes and
ordinances on the complex, a copy of said agreement being attached to ordinance 0-90-222 as exhibit B.
C. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each

10-8-12: METRA COMMUTER STATION REGULATIONS:
A. Fees For Daily Parking:
1. Daily parking zones have a parking time of twelve (12) hours, the fee for each twelve (12) hour period, or part thereof, shall be one dollar seventy
five cents ($1.75). (Ord. 0-10-15, 6-28-2010)
2. No parking will be allowed between twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., except for overnight permits as described in
subsection F of this section.
3. The city administrator shall cause to be erected parking fee collection equipment or coin boxes for deposit of the fee for parking in such zone.
B. Deposit Of Slugs Or Foreign Coins: It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any slug or substitute for United States coins or cent pieces in parking
meters or coin boxes.
C. Tampering: It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, tamper with, open, wilfully break or destroy any parking fee collection equipment, coin box,
regulatory sign or to damage the post to which it is attached.
D. Responsibility Of Registered Owner:
1. The registration of a motor vehicle with the secretary of state in the name of the alleged violator, or the issuance of a vehicle sticker by a municipality
to the alleged violator, shall constitute prima facie proof that the alleged violator was in control of, or was the operator of, the motor vehicle at the time
of such alleged violation.
2. Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to law and who leases such vehicles to others, after receiving written notice of a
violation of this section involving such vehicles, shall provide the police with a written statement of the name and address of the lessee at the time of
such offense and the identifying number on the registration plates of the vehicle. (Ord. 0-96-62, 8-19-1996, eff. 8-19-1996)
E. Fines And Penalties: It shall be the duty of police officers of this city to report to the police department:
1. The state license number of any vehicle that has been parked in violation to the contrary of any of the provisions of this section;
2. The time such vehicle parked in violation of any of the provisions of this section;
3. Such other information as may be necessary for a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation; and
4. Penalty for failures to pay required fee will be seventy five dollars ($75.00) if paid within ten (10) days from the date of violation, and one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) if more than ten (10) days from the date of the violation. (Ord. 0-16-19, 6-13-2016)
F. Permits For Parking In City Parking Facilities:
1. The city administrator shall cause suitable permit stickers to be prepared and made available for issuance and sale to persons desiring to park in
those portions of the city parking facilities in which parking is restricted to holders of such permits. The number of permits issued shall not exceed the
number of parking spaces actually available for parking, unless the city administrator determines, on the basis of surveys of parking space vacancy
rates and other relevant criteria, that the sale of an additional number of permits is justified, in which event, an additional number of permits may be
sold at the direction of the city administrator. Permit stickers shall designate the city parking facility for which issued, and shall be issued and sold for
monthly periods.
2. Under the direction of the city administrator, permit stickers shall be sold during regular business hours at the city offices, and shall be sold in
accordance with chronological priority of application for such permits, except that the city administrator may establish a schedule for sale only to
persons residing within the corporate limits of the city or persons who own or are employed by businesses within the corporate limits of the city, prior
to any offer of such permits for sale to the general public. (Ord. 0-96-62, 8-19-1996, eff. 8-19-1996)
3. The fee for a monthly "daily" permit purchased from the city shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for a permit that allows parking every business day for a
designated month. A one dollar fifty cent ($1.50) fee applies for each business day period. (Ord. 0-97-10, 2-18-1997, eff. 2-28-1997)
4. The fee for a daily "overnight" permit purchased from the city shall be three dollars fifty cents ($3.50) for a permit that allows twenty four (24) hour
parking. A three dollar fifty cent ($3.50) fee applies for each twenty four (24) hour period. (Ord. 0-10-15, 6-28-2010)
Chapter 9
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT, SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD
10-9-1: LIGHTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 400/470
A. It shall be unlawful to operate or park on any street any vehicle not equipped with adequate lights conforming to the requirements of State law1,
provided that vehicles may be parked at nighttime without lights on any street or portion thereof where parking is permitted.
B. Use Of Headlamps: On approaching another vehicle proceeding in the opposite direction or on overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same
direction and, in either case, when a vehicle is within three hundred fifty feet (350') or less of same, any person in charge of a motorcycle or motor
vehicle equipped with electric headlight or headlights shall dim or drop such headlight or headlights. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-2: SIGNAL LAMPS AND DEVICES:
A. Every motor vehicle and trailer shall be equipped with a signal lamp or signal device which is so constructed and located on the vehicle as to give a
signal of intention to stop which shall be red in color and signals of intention to turn to the right or left, all of which signals shall be plainly visible and
understandable in normal sunlight and at night from a distance of one hundred feet (100') to the front and rear, but shall not project a glaring or dazzling
light; except that a stop signal need be visible only from the rear. Any trailer, having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000) pounds or less including
the weight of the trailer and maximum load, need not be equipped with such turn signal device unless the distance from the center of the steering
wheel of the towing vehicle to the left hand outside limits of such trailer body exceeds twenty four inches (24")2.
B. All mechanical signal devices shall be self-illuminated when in actual use. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-3: BRAKES:
It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle upon a street or highway in the City unless such vehicle is equipped with good and sufficient brakes in good
working condition, as required by the State Traffic Law3 or to operate any vehicle which is so loaded that the operator does not have ready access to the
mechanics operating the brakes of such vehicle. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-4: HORNS AND WARNING DEVICES:
Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a good and sufficient audible signaling device in efficient working condition. Such signaling device shall be
sounded when necessary to give timely warning of the approach of a vehicle, but such horn or other signaling device shall not be sounded for any purpose
than as a warning of impending danger.
No motor vehicle other than an emergency vehicle shall be equipped with a siren or gong signaling device4. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-5: MUFFLERS; PREVENTION OF NOISE, GAS AND SMOKE:
A. Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise
and annoying smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass or similar device upon a motor vehicle on a street or highway.
B. It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of any person5. (Ord. 0-77-
17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-6: MIRRORS:
Motor vehicles of either division which are so constructed or loaded as to obstruct the driver's view to the rear thereof from the driver's position, shall be
equipped with a mirror so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the street or highway for a distance of at least two hundred feet (200') to the rear of
such vehicle6. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-7: WINDSHIELD REQUIREMENTS; WIPERS7:
A. No person shall drive any motor vehicle with any sign, poster or other nontransparent material upon the front windshield, side wings, side or rear
windows of such vehicle which obstructs the driver's clear view of the street or highway.
B. No person shall drive any motor vehicle with any objects placed or suspended between the driver and the front windshield or between the driver and the
rear window which obstructs the driver's clear view of the street or highway.
C. The windshield on every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a device for cleaning rain, snow or other moisture from the windshield, which device shall
be so constructed as to be controlled or operated by the driver of the vehicle. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-8: TIRE EQUIPMENT8:
A. Improved Roads:
1. No metal-tired vehicle including tractors, motor vehicles of the second division, traction engines and other similar vehicles, shall be operated over
any improved street or highway of the City if such vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any blocks, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 401/470
any projection of metal or wood which projects radially between the tread or traffic surface of the tire; except that this prohibition shall not apply to
track type motor vehicles when that part of the vehicle coming on contact with the road surface does not contain any projections of any kind likely to
injure the surface of the road; provided however, that tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles may be operated which have upon their road
wheels V-shaped diagonal or other cleats arranged in such a manner as to be continuously in contact with the road surface provided that the gross
weight upon such wheels per inch of width of such cleats in contact with the road surface, when measured in the direction of the axle of the vehicle,
does not exceed eight hundred (800) pounds.
2. No motor vehicle shall be operated upon the improved streets or highways of the City which shall be equipped with any anti-skid or nonslick device
so constructed that any rigid or nonflexible portion of same comes in contact with the pavement; provided, that this subsection shall not apply to
agricultural tractors or traction engines or similar metal tired vehicles which have anti-skid devices upon the road wheels and which are otherwise
permitted to be used under the provisions of this Title.
3. All motor vehicles and all trailers or other vehicles in tow thereof, or thereunto attached, operating upon any roadway, shall have tires of rubber or
some material of equal resiliency; provided that solid tires shall be considered defective and shall not be permitted to be used if the rubber or other
material has been worn or otherwise reduced to a thickness of less than three-fourths inch (3/4") or if such tires have been so worn or otherwise
damaged as to cause undue vibration when the vehicle is in motion or to cause undue concentration of the wheel load on the surface of the road;
and provided further, that the requirements of this Section shall not apply to agricultural tractors or traction engines or to agricultural machinery,
including wagons being used for agricultural purposes in tow thereof, or to road rollers or road building machinery. All motor vehicles of the second
division, as defined herein, which are designed and used for the carrying of more than seven (7) persons operating upon any roadway shall have
pneumatic tires, and all other motor vehicles of the second division operating upon any roadway at a speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour shall
be equipped with pneumatic tires.
B. Oil Treated Roads: No tractor, traction engine, motor truck or other similar vehicle shall be operated across, over or along any street or highway of the
City which has been oil treated, if any such vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any block, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug or any
projection of metal or wood which projects radially beyond the tread or traffic surface of the tire; except that this prohibition shall not apply to tractors or
traction engines equipped with what is known as crawler type tractors when the same does not contain any projections of any kind likely to injure the
surface of the road, nor to tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles which have upon their road wheels V-shaped, diagonal or other cleats
arranged in such a manner as to be continuously in contact with the road surface. In no event shall the oil mat surface of any oil treated public road be
used as an area or space for turning any tractor or other farm machinery and carrying on or performing any farming operations upon the adjacent land.
Provided, that nothing in this Section contained shall prohibit the operation of tractors, traction engines or motor trucks across any oil treated road in
order to reach adjacent lands, or the operation of any such vehicles upon the treated portion thereof over which they may be operated or the operation
of any such vehicle on oil treated roads if in passing along said road they travel over the portion of said road which does not constitute the oil mat
surface created by said oil treatment. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-9: SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD9:
A. Weight: It shall be unlawful to drive on any street or highway in the City any motor vehicle with a weight, including load, in excess of that permitted by
the State Traffic Law for driving on improved highways, or with weight distributed in a manner not conforming to such law.
B. Height, Width And Length Of Vehicles: It shall be unlawful to drive on any street or highway in the City any motor vehicle with a height, width or length in
excess of that permitted by the State Traffic Law for driving on improved highways.
C. Spilling Loads On Streets Or Highways Prohibited:
1. No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any street or highway unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from
dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction or water or other
substance may be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or maintaining such roadway.
2. No person shall operate on any street or highway any vehicle with any load unless said load or any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to
prevent said covering or load from becoming loose, detached or in any manner a hazard to other users of the street or highway.
3. Drivers or operators of vehicles depositing mud or other debris on Municipal streets shall be responsible for immediate removal of the mud or debris.
D. Liability If Street, Highway Or Structure Is Damaged:
1. Any person driving any vehicle, object or contrivance upon any street or highway or highway structure is liable for all damage which the street or
highway or highway structure may sustain as a result of any illegal operation, driving or moving of such vehicle, object or contrivance, or as a result
of operating, driving or moving any vehicle, object or contrivance, weighing in excess of the maximum weight specified in the State statutes, but
authorized by a special State permit issued as provided by the State statutes. The measure of liability is the cost of repairing a facility partially
damaged or the depreciated replacement costs of a facility damaged beyond repair, together with all other expenses incurred in providing a
temporary detour, including a temporary structure, to serve the needs of traffic during the period of repair or replacement of the damaged street,
highway or highway structure.
2. Whenever such driver is not the owner of such vehicle, object or contrivance, but is so operating, driving or moving the same with the express or
implied permission of said owner, then the owner and driver are jointly and severally liable to the extent provided in subsection D1 of this Section.
3. Recovery may be sought in a civil action by the City.
E. Projecting Loads; Width, Length And Height: The maximum width, length and height of any vehicle and its load shall not exceed the limits expressed in
the State Traffic Law. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-9-10: LIMITED LOAD STREETS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 402/470
Whenever the weight of vehicles permitted on a street is limited by ordinance and signs indicating such limitations are posted, it shall be unlawful to
operate a vehicle in excess of such weight on such street, except for the purpose of making delivery or picking up a load, in which case such vehicle may
be driven on such street for not more than the minimum distance necessary for the purpose.
The following streets are hereby declared to be limited load streets, and vehicles of a weight in excess of five thousand (5,000) pounds are hereby
prohibited from using such streets except as provided in this Section:
Clarendon Street from Elmhurst Road to Wheeling Road.

(Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
Chapter 10
BICYCLES
10-10-1: BICYCLE EQUIPMENT:
A. Headlamp: Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at
least five hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type which shall be visible from all distances from fifty feet (50') to
three hundred feet (300') to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlights on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible
from a distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector.
B. Signaling Bell: No person shall operate a bicycle not equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least one
hundred feet (100'), except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle.
C. Brakes: Each bicycle shall be equipped with adequate brakes. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)
10-10-2: RIDING REGULATIONS:
A. Abreast, Single File: When two (2) or more persons in a group are operating bicycles, they shall not ride abreast but in single file.
B. Clinging To Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle in the City to cling to or attach himself or his bicycle to any other moving
vehicle.
C. Emerging From Alleys, Driveways Or Garages: The operator of any bicycle emerging from any alley, driveway or garage shall stop immediately prior to
driving onto or across a sidewalk or onto a sidewalk line projected across an alley, and shall exercise extreme care in those cases.
D. Intoxication, Drugs: It shall be unlawful for any person under the influence of drugs to operate a bicycle in the City.
E. Lights: No bicycle shall be operated within the City between thirty (30) minutes after sunset or thirty (30) minutes before sunrise, without a clear, white,
properly lighted headlight, visible under normal atmospheric conditions from the front thereof, for not less than five hundred feet (500') and firmly
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 403/470
attached to the bicycle, and without a red reflector, firmly attached to the rear of the bicycle, which is clearly visible in the headlights of an automobile
for a distance of at least one hundred feet (100').
F. Parking Bicycles; Interference: Bicycles shall not, at any time and in any place, be indiscriminately parked by anyone along buildings in such a manner
as to interfere with pedestrians or along roadways or sidewalks where they may interfere with traffic, or with persons getting into or out of automobiles.
No person shall move or in any manner interfere with any bicycle which is properly parked, nor shall any person interfere or in any manner hinder any
person from properly parking a bicycle, except that the members of the Police or Fire Departments may move or in proper cases prevent the parking of
a bicycle when, in the judgment of the police or fire officers, such action is necessary in order to properly safeguard persons or property.
G. Keeping To The Right: All bicycles when operated on roadways shall be kept to the right and shall be operated as nearly as practicable at the righthand
edge of the roadway.
H. Speed: No bicycle shall be operated faster than is reasonable and proper, and each bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard to the safety of
the rider or other persons and property.
I. Traffic Regulations: Any person operating a bicycle in the City shall obey all traffic signs and signals, and shall obey all other traffic rules and regulations
applicable thereto.
J. Turns: Turns in traffic shall be in accordance with the provisions relating to turns in traffic in this Title. (Ord. 0-77-17, 6-7-1977)

Chapter 12
VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
10-12-1: TRAFFIC VIOLATION TICKETS:

nature of the offense, the make, year, registration and license numbers of the vehicle involved, the name and address of the driver where possible, and
notifying the offender to appear in court on a specific time and date, as is designated for hearing such cases. In the event that the offender does not
appear at the time, date and place specified, the arresting officer may sign a complaint for the issuance of a warrant for the offender's arrest. (Ord. 0-77-
17, 6-7-1977; amd. Ord. 0-98-29, 7-20-1998, eff. 7-30-1998)

Chapter 13
MOTORIZED SKATEBOARDS
10-13-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this chapter "motorized skateboard" means any device that has a deck or platform on which a person may stand or sit, with two (2) or
more wheels, and that is self-propelled by any type of motor or engine; provided, however, that the term "motorized skateboard" shall not include the
following: a) a motor vehicle1; b) a motorcycle2; c) a motor driven cycle3; d) a motorized pedalcycle4; or e) a motorized wheelchair5 or other device
designed and used to transport a person with a disability. (Ord. 0-03-36, 9-15-2003, eff. 9-25-2003)
10-13-2: LIMITATION ON USE:
With the exception of authorized employees and officers of the city of Prospect Heights, United States postal service employees, and other authorized
governmental employees, no person shall operate or ride a motorized skateboard on or within any of the following places within the city: public streets and
rights of way, public sidewalks, public parking lots or areas, public parks and any other public property. (Ord. 0-03-36, 9-15-2003, eff. 9-25-2003)
10-13-3: FINE; IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION:
Any person violating this chapter shall be subject to a citation and imposition of a fine pursuant to the general penalty provisions set forth in section 10-12-
3 of this title, as may be amended from time to time. Additionally, any person who has been issued three (3) or more citations for violations of this chapter
within any twelve (12) month period shall be required to surrender, at the time of issuance of the third citation, the motorized skateboard to the police
officer or other authorized official who issues the citation. The surrendered motorized skateboard shall be impounded and held by the city of Prospect
Heights police department and shall be returned to its owner only after one of the following sets of conditions have been met:
A. The person against whom the citation was issued shall have paid: 1) all outstanding fines and 2) the fees and costs of the city in the amount of one
hundred dollars ($100.00); or
B. The person against whom the citation was issued shall have: 1) paid or caused to be paid all outstanding fines, and 2) presented to the city proof that a
determination of not guilty was made for the cited offense. (Ord. 0-03-36, 9-15-2003, eff. 9-25-2003)
10-13-4: PAYMENTS TO AVOID PROSECUTION:
A person charged with a violation of this chapter may avoid prosecution by paying to the city the following amounts for each violation within the time
specified:
Time Period Amount Of Fine
0-10 days $25.00
After 10 days 50.00
After thirty (30) days the fine must be paid in full or a court appearance will be required. This section shall not affect the redemption fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) set forth in section 10-3-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 0-03-36, 9-15-2003, eff. 9-25-2003)
Chapter 14
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM
10-14-1: IMPLEMENTATION; DEFINITIONS:
A. Implementation: There is hereby implemented an automated traffic law enforcement system of the city of Prospect Heights.
B. Definitions:
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM: Either a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red
light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a red signal indication in violation of section 11-306 of the
Illinois vehicle code or a similar provision of this city code, or a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with the visual
signals on a school bus, as specified in sections 12-803 and 12-805 of the Illinois vehicle code1, to produce recorded images of motor vehicles that fail
to stop before meeting or overtaking, from either direction, any school bus stopped at any location for the purpose of receiving or discharging pupils in
violation of section 11-1414 of the Illinois vehicle code2 or a similar provision of this code.
ORDINANCE ENFORCEMENT ADMINISTRATOR: The ordinance enforcement administrator provided for in title 9, chapter 4 of this code.
RECORDED IMAGES: Images recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system, on either two (2) or more photographs, two (2) or more
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 405/470
micrographs, two (2) or more electronic images or a video recording showing the motor vehicle, capturing and displaying images of the vehicle violating
traffic control signals, or being operated with expired registration, together with at least one clearly recorded image identifying the vehicle's license
plate. The recorded image shall also display the time, date and location of the violation. (Ord. 0-13-24, 11-25-2013)
10-14-2: SIGNAGE:
A. Any intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system shall have a sign posted which is clearly visible to approaching traffic
indicating that the intersection is being monitored by an automated traffic law enforcement system. The city shall provide notice to drivers by posting
the location of any intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system on the city website.
B. A school bus equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system shall be posted with a sign indicating that the school bus is being monitored
by an automated traffic law enforcement system. (Ord. 0-13-24, 11-25-2013)
10-14-3: SCOPE:
A. The automated traffic law enforcement system shall be used to detect and enforce violations of section 11-306 (traffic control devices), 11-1414
(approaching, overtaking and passing a school bus) or 3-413 (vehicle registration) of the Illinois vehicle code, as amended from time to time.
B. The city administrator shall post on the city's website a list of the: 1) intersections equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system and 2)
school districts using school buses equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system. (Ord. 0-13-24, 11-25-2013)
10-14-4: VIOLATIONS, REVIEW, NOTICE, SERVICE:
A. Adjudication Of Violations: Adjudication of violations detected under this chapter shall be performed by the ordinance enforcement department.
B. Preliminary Review Of Recorded Images: Prior to service of a notice of violation, the associated recorded image shall be reviewed by a law
enforcement officer or retired law enforcement officer of the city, who shall inspect the image and determine whether the motor vehicle violated section
11-306, 11-1414 or 3-413 of the Illinois vehicle code, and whether one of the defenses enumerated hereinafter is visibly applicable upon inspection of
the recorded image.
C. Notice: Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation of one of the foregoing provisions and that no defense applies, the ordinance
enforcement administrator shall serve a notice of violation upon the registered vehicle owner in the manner herein provided.
D. Method Of Service: The notice shall be delivered by first class mail, postage prepaid, within thirty (30) days after the Illinois secretary of state notifies
the city of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, but in no event later than ninety (90) days after the violation.
E. Prima Facie Evidence: Each notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging
a violation of the above noted statutory and local ordinance provisions and shall establish prima facie evidence of a violation.
F. Records: The chief of police or his designee shall retain a copy of all violation notices, recorded images and other correspondence mailed to the alleged
violator. (Ord. 0-13-24, 11-25-2013)
10-14-5: CONTENTS OF VIOLATION NOTICE:
A. Each notice of violation shall include the following:
1. The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, as indicated by the records of the secretary of state, or, if such information is
outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database;
2. The registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation;
3. The violation charged, with specific reference to that section of this code, or Illinois motor vehicle code, allegedly violated;
4. The location where the violation occurred;
5. The date and time of the violation;
6. A copy of the recorded images;
7. A website address, accessible through the internet, where the person may view the recorded images of the violation;
8. The amount of the civil penalty imposed under section 10-14-7 of this chapter and the date by which the civil penalty shall be paid if liability for the
violation is not going to be contested;
9. A statement that the recorded images are evidence of a violation of: a) a red light signal violation, b) approaching, overtaking and passing a school
bus or c) expired registration;
10. A warning that failure to either pay the civil penalty or to contest liability within twenty one (21) days of the mailing of the notice of violation is an
admission of liability and may result in a suspension of the driving privileges of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle in addition to other
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 406/470
specified penalties for failing to appear at the hearing or pay the fine in advance of the hearing;
11. A statement that the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle may elect to proceed either by paying the fine stated in the notice of violation or by
challenging the charge in an administrative hearing;
12. The date, time and place of the administrative hearing at which the charge may be contested on its merits, a date that shall be no less than fifteen
(15) nor more than thirty (30) days from the mailing or other service of the notice of violation; and
13. The signature of the technician reviewing the recorded images and confirming that a violation took place. (Ord. 0-13-24, 11-25-2013)
10-14-6: DEFENSES:
A. The hearing officer may consider the following defenses to an alleged violation of either section 11-306 or 3-413 of the Illinois vehicle code detected
under this chapter:
1. The motor vehicle and/or registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the exclusive control of or in the
possession of the owner at the time of the red light signal violation, which defense may be demonstrated through the submission of a certified copy
of a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates filed with a law enforcement agency prior to the time of the alleged violation;
2. The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the light was red either: a) to yield the right of way to an emergency vehicle, or b) as
part of a funeral procession;
3. The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the light was red at the direction of a police officer acting within the scope of his
duties;
4. The motor vehicle was being operated by someone other than the registered vehicle owner or lessee at the time of the red light signal violation,
which defense shall require written notification to the city and shall only be deemed a valid defense insofar as the registered vehicle owner or lessee
provides the name and address of the person operating the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense. Failure to notify the city in writing of the name
and address of the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense in advance of the hearing date or date on which the civil penalty is due
will result in a presumption that the registered owner or lessee was the operator of the vehicle at the time of the offense and will result in a finding of
liability unless one of the other defenses is proved; and
5. The motor vehicle came to a complete stop and did not enter the intersection during the cycle of the red light indication even if the motor vehicle
stopped at a point past the stop line or crosswalk where a driver is required to stop and no pedestrians or bicyclists were present.
B. The hearing officer may consider the following defenses to an alleged violation of section 11-1414 of the Illinois vehicle code detected under this
chapter:
1. The motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle were stolen before the violation occurred and not under the control of or in the
possession of the owner at the time of the violation;
2. The driver of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer for a violation of section 11-1414 of the Illinois vehicle code
within one-eighth (1/8) of a mile and fifteen (15) minutes of the violation that was recorded by the system; and
3. The visual signals required by sections 12-803 and 12-805 of the Illinois vehicle code were damaged, not activated, not present in violation of
sections 12-803 and 12-805 of the Illinois vehicle code, or inoperable. (Ord. 0-13-24, 11-25-2013)
10-14-7: PENALTY:
A. For violations of section 11-306 (traffic control devices) or 3-413 (vehicle registration) of the Illinois vehicle code, unless the driver of the motor vehicle in
question received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer at the time of the alleged violation, a motor vehicle owner is subject to a civil penalty not
exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a proved violation of this chapter, plus an additional penalty of not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for failure to pay the original penalty or contest the violation at an administrative hearing in a timely manner, if the motor vehicle is recorded
by an automated traffic law enforcement system.
B. For violations of section 11-1414 (approaching, overtaking and passing a school bus) of the Illinois vehicle code, unless the driver of the motor vehicle
received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer at the time of the violation, the motor vehicle owner is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a first time violation or five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second or subsequent violation, plus an additional penalty
of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for failure to pay the original penalty in a timely manner, if the motor vehicle is recorded by an
automated traffic law enforcement system.
C. Any penalty imposed for a violation of this chapter is a civil penalty and is not a violation of a traffic regulation governing the movement of motor
vehicles and shall not be transmitted to the Illinois secretary of state to be recorded on a driving record of the vehicle owner.
D. All violations detected under this chapter and processed by the city's ordinance enforcement department under title 9, chapter 4 of this code shall be
deemed vehicle compliance violations related to the condition and use of vehicle equipment.
E. Any civil penalty imposed for a violation of this chapter shall be paid within forty nine (49) days following the administrative hearing at which the civil
penalty was imposed.
F. Subject to subsection A of this section, no additional fee shall be charged to the alleged violator for exercising his or her right to an administrative
hearing.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=920 407/470
G. Whenever a registered owner of a vehicle has failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owing the city as a result of five (5) offenses for automated
